hc4FcL3cdt0I_IvrDMhp2A.review_text: This place is really cute but not secret/hard-to-find at all as a lot of things I've read suggest.  So that's a good thing!    We went around maybe 7 pm on Friday and every seat in the place was filled so we went down the street to Grant and Green for some cheap PBR (I guess that's pretty much a redundant phrase but I'm going to leave it.)    Around 8:30/9 pm we got the urge to take off but swung by Church Key to see if any seats had opened up.  And indeed they had!  The entire upstairs loft was empty, so we grabbed a perch up there.  The atmosphere was very cool, laid-back and kind of a luxe-vintage thing going on.  They had a really nice diverse beer selection and I saw a bunch of people drinking the Sofia Coppola champagne-minis which are awesome.    Everyone seemed friendly and there was even a huge pug dog eating french fries at the banquette in front as we left.  The fries looked good so we asked his owner where they were from.  They were from Mo's down the street so that was our next stop of the evening...

wVv8-yw8wlzDyYJMDEXFVw.review_text: Great vibe at this bar with good beer and friendly service. There was a live DJ spinning on Wednesday night which was pretty cool. I loved how low key this place was without feeling like a dive. It was recommended by a bartender at La Trappe, so if you like that bar, this will definitely be your scene too.

5Z-3tcM07Pyc4mOF2Rjt6Q.review_text: What makes a good bar?  Is it the mixologist churning out innovative and potent cocktails?  Is it the carefully selected lineup of beers on tap covering the whole spectrum of the public's hop palate?  Is it the crowd that fills the booths and bar stools?  Or is it the architecture of the bar itself?  I don't know if the bartender was a good mixer and I wasn't pleased with their beers on tap.  The crowd was a good mix of urban intellectuals (I went on a night where there was trivia), but in the end I fell a little in love with the ambiance created by my non-sentient surroundings.  Love the red couch along the back wall.  Love the few small tables and high tops, which left the space feeling intimate.  Love that there is an upstairs.  And the lighting was perfect for good conversation of any and all sorts.  So what makes for a good bar?  A good bar is a space where you want to drink and converse and you feel more of yourself than you did before.  Bars like this make me feel more sophisticated, but casually so.  The Church Key to my heart!

QRHS2i4DWS6R0fpkCalvaQ.review_text: This place is tiny but darling inside. Sit at the bar for an idle drink with a friend and the bartender is sure to provide some good banter and/or recommendations from the impressive drink list, which includes some pretty obscure and delicious beer from around the world. If you have a group or want a dark corner there's a loft upstairs as well.

3yiIhApUdcsNHnMx76_GVg.review_text: Really liked this place and definitely want to go back.  They've got a great beer selection and the bartender of the night was really knowledgeable. Good music too!

IXAYirFUR2Gs0zNkJi0rXA.review_text: Loved the ambiance early in the evening meeting Jason. They have a thing going on there that is soft and lively. Good vibe, nice ambiance and Katherine is a nice girlfriend to the Biz. She and He are a hot couple . Try it out .

4Po_4vgdBFk2GPeKfJqVww.review_text: I hate to admit it, but yes, I do judge a first date on the bar he chooses to take me to.  So, when this fella asked me to meet him at Church Key, I knew things were looking up.  With what feels like 100 IPA's on the menu, i felt giddy with all the possibilities that could be tasted and swallowed that night (get your mind out of the gutter, sicko!)  I have to admit, I must have clearly looked a bit overwhelmed, so the bartender came up and suggested one that I might like and he was right...hoppy goodness!  Small space that gets kinda crowded...but the people are chill and the bartender adorable and helpful.    Some of the brews are STRONG and I felt kinda F'd up after only 2 glasses.  (Yeah, my date was no fool...he knew exactly what he was doing when picking this place!)  Looking forward to coming back and tackling some more of those IPA's!

3waAQbBf5b3R4LKLXeSDdw.review_text: My girlfriend and I stopped in this bar last night by chance for "a drink." The beer was amazing. The bartender and a few other folks at the bar were really funny, nice people. Good music, good jokes, good times. This place is a hidden gem in North Beach- a bit pricey when you compare it to other awesome beer spots such as the Fireside in Alameda or the Tornado on Height but about the same price as the Monk's Kettle and the atmosphere here is nice and chill so worth paying a few extra bucks. They also have some interesting beers on tap so our "one drink" turned into a couple. Next time I'm in the neighborhood I will stop on in for another tasty beer adventure...though with so many amazing beers to chose from... and with the affable bartender...and chill relaxed vibe... it can be a bit dangerous if you have to be somewhere the next day-be warned that you may end up "tasting" more delicious beers than you bargained for.

cMoQqT_j_FD1gO6EEZzOIg.review_text: Hey lets go to the loungey type place that serves only beer, said no one ever.  A unique mix. A lounge that serves only beer. I'm not complaining, I had a good time and a couple of rounds.  Large beer selection, which will cater to your needs and desires. Not those deep, dark desires. Don't tell the bartender about those. Just the beer you desire, and they should have something you like.   The upstairs is cool, with some plush seating, nice artwork and good decor.   They did close early on a Thursday and this is where I discovered that when a place does last call in SF, it's usually half an hour before they're suppose to close down. It's like being in college all over again.  Something different and worth checking out.

u7yxMVwLli7Aj8dZwQnOGA.review_text: This place was great. They had an excellent beer selection and described them similar to wines with the ingredients and tastes. For those of you that don't prefer to branch out, they even have an American beer that rotates - it could be Pabst, could be Bud Lite.

TppZ9nrqpH3Y9NHmP_8Bbg.review_text: I like north beach... this is on my fav list for the area but it's def nothing special.  The atmosphere is nice... cool lil' venue; it never gets too crowded, but they only serve beer and wine.  I don't know if it's a regular occurrence but a couple of their beers on tap were tapped out one recent evening.  If they started serving the hard stuff and didn't have issues with running out of beer I'd definitely bump my rating up to four stars.    Feel free to ask the bartenders about their unique beer selection.  They are usually more than happy to share.

bpgbVPJcG-wQ4cNBcPPIxw.review_text: I was in the city livin it up because it was my birthday, so we were bar hopping from one end to the other, and we stopped in at the Church Key, walked in and saw there was a group with name tags, ah I do like the parties that involve you wearing name tags, but they were a private party that had just ended.  Also upstairs in the Church Key was Open Mic night, but honestly even though I was sitting at the bar downstairs I rarely heard a joke being told, either great sound system downstairs or nothing laugh worthy was being told haha, sorry.  (not sorry)  Bar tender for the night was Thomas, and he is a pretty cool dude, told him that I'm fairly new in the beer world so I got to try a few samples of what they had on tap, after finding a few that I liked I went ahead and ordered a glass, can you believe the 1st one was on the house because it was my bday! WOOT WOOT!  Lots of fun was had here everyone who came in was friendly and fun, even met a man who worked for Google, but didn't liked to be called a googlier haha.  Music was playing the in the background, for the life of me I couldn't tell you who, but then a song came on and I was like hold up isn't that George Michael and of course everyone said NO WAY this is Queen, and then I was like nope thats George, being a George Michael fan from back in the Wham days, I know the man's voice, and Thomas checked the IPod and said well shit it's both. It was funny fun night.   Had a great time down at the Church Key, if you are in the area go give it a try!

ksLEtpBAdVGaEramRXYYSQ.review_text: This place is a great option if you want to grab a drink with a friend or two. The downstairs is small so I wouldn't suggest taking a large group but the service was good, the music was pretty descent and we were able to grab seats right at the bar. Most importantly they have a serious beer selection and the bar tender was able to provide some solid recommendations based on what our preferences were. I would go back here for a drink any day.

Vcadamdv04NuyAiRIWSkOg.review_text: First off let me start by saying "I LOVE BEER!"...  Now that i got that off my chest, lets continue.  This is a cool spot.  To me, it seems like one of those high class places for intellectuals but welcomes everyone and is not snobby at all about it.  There was so much beer here that i didnt know what to do.  I seriously must have looked like a deer caught in the headlights when i looked over the menu.  But the bartender was really friendly and asked what do i like and offered me some recommendations.  They really do know their stuff here.  Down to the very last bit of what hints of different flavors are there with subtleties and what not.  And im talking about beer, not wine.  So thats a plus.  When someone can tell me a lot about it, it shows that they are passionate about it.  I weill come back, and i will ask for more recommendations.

DvcAC_nlKaTDsHcA8Slagw.review_text: Intimate. Understated. A welcome sanctuary from the North Beach madness for beer lovers in the neighborhood.  I really love Church Key. For a bar that is tucked in this narrow nook, it is chocked full of yummy brews from obscure domestic micro-brews to evergreen Belgian favorites. Unlike other bars along Grant St., this isn't a "chug a beer" bar. Instead, come and take your time, catch up with a friend, and savor your beer. It is a wonderfully cozy space that is never too loud so you can have great conversations here. I particularly like the space "upstairs" although sitting at the bar (if you can snag a seat) is the way to go if you want to engage with the bartenders who are always more than willing to offer you suggestions of new brews to try.   No neon signboard here but instead look out for an illuminated key as your beacon for a night of beer discovery at Church Key. I'm glad I did.

LOKBrpZFR_rWiEkuULrLgQ.review_text: This place is decent.  Pretty nice ambiance and a fairly good beer selection, albeit extremely predictable.  They've got some Allagash (White/Curieux), Dogfish Head (90 Min/Midas Touch/Palo Santo Marron), Delirium Tremens, some De Ranke, Nogne, Duchesse de Bourgog....(yawn).....zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz­zzzzzzzzzzz.  Ok, maybe I've become too much of a beer snob for my own good.  But really, nearby La Trappe dominates this place, and that's not even considering La Trappe's awesome moules frites.  Church Key prices are also pretty high, although not unexpected for a high-end North Beach beer bar.  One interesting feature on the menu is the $2 "mystery beer."   ***SPOILER ALERT!*** It's something crappy, almost definitely some variety of bland American macro adjunct lager.  (As I always say, "Adjunct?  More like adJUNK!")  If you're lucky, it'll be PBR.  If you're unlucky, well, let's just say I hope you have lots of Advil and easy toilet access the next day.  Still though, it's another place to get a good beer in the city, and with 90% of the beer consumed in this country still being that awful Bud/Miller/Coors crap, we sure as hell need it.

ex1ypGlvo2OiNhSDzWSDGQ.review_text: This is a classy and cozy place -- the perfect mellow alternative to Grant & Green or Mojito.  We went for an "anti-Superbowl party," (advertised on Yelp) for which Danielle, the bartender, made incredible bean dip and brought in delicious salsa and chips.  She is extremely knowledgeable about the ever-changing beer list and gave us a few suggestions (Three Philosphers and Allagash -- loved the latter, so-so on the former).  This place is packed on Friday and Saturday nights--it's definitely a place to check out when you make the rounds in North Beach!

ssuWkMne1wQ6_WmxmXhl5Q.review_text: Awesome hole in the wall bar up on Grant Ave.  If you aren't paying attention you will most likely walk right by.    Arrived right after it opened on a Tuesday afternoon.  I was the only one here for a bit and enjoyed shooting the shit with the bartender.  She definitely knew her beer.  Though the stated policy is that "samples will cost you," I was afforded one and subsequently enjoyed a goblet.  I went with the Heirloom Pumpkin Barleywine.  Definitely enjoyed.  This is my kind of place.  The bar area is not terribly bright and decorated eclectically but with a purpose.  Ween's Quebec album was playing in the background and just set the mood for a really peaceful drink.    It seems like some pretty hard to find stuff comes through on a pretty regular basis.   I will be back.

kMBb6jZm2U0fcksceorcSw.review_text: I wish I could transport this place to Sacramento. Very low key and chill. The space is tiny and intimate and I wouldn't recommend bringing a big group of people...it isn't that type of place. The beer menu is huge and seems intimidating at first, but it's broken down by variety. Just close your eyes and pick a random page. I can say the hibiscus beer and the coconut porter were delicious! Props to the owner...there was a douchebag, drunk and obviously trying to network him, sitting next to the bf and I. The owner kept drinking his PBR, not having it, without being a shit to him. When my guy from Indiana, slightly awed, asked him some questions about the bar, the owner was the nicest guy. We went back twice in one week. It would def. be my first choice for a beer.

9vT5aq2pVYb4gpnY-9Bpzw.review_text: friendly people, great beer selection, small knit group, cheap prices  need I say more,  Definitely a spot for a beer enthusiast to visit while living or vacationing in san fran.

dy4OvKg-9GBhgGaZFaKqTQ.review_text: Great beers on tap, and also in bottles. weird space to sit down stairs there aren't many places to do so ,we took a walk upstairs and there was a party going on but we kinda fit in and had a blast with them drinking beer so if you like beer and you're in north beach this is your spot. A younger crowd generally... But probably the best bet if you find yourself in North Beach...

tyOr6NpS35q7fnPjHNQ9KQ.review_text: We had a great time Monday afternoon. No one there, we had the booth to  ourselves and the beer was flowing. First time there but not the last time!

gi0khkeuBNFZiERf6OQJ3Q.review_text: Best beer selection.  Friendly bartenders, and the COOLEST FUCKING WALLPAPER EVER.  Yeah, that's right, I said it.

mXPpMRWMYXCZUqDPD4Fycw.review_text: Great place to go after work to try a bunch of different beers.  Thrillist turned me on to this hidden spot, and it didn't disappoint.     Insane selection and yet a little too insane at times.  Some of the beers were a bit expensive, they have moderately priced ones too.  Not sure how well they will do with the really expensive beers since this area tends to attract the party type that sticks to the basics to get loose.   The inside is small.  Coming here on a bar hop over the weekend isn't ideal; there's just not that much room to move around.    Props to them for being different and opening up a unique spot for beer lovers.  Not since living in London have I found such a spot that caries as many beers.

CZU1RZavKV2fHhTvRRWdew.review_text: awesome selection of beers, limited seating, but friendly and knowledgeable staff - great for beer lovers !  relaxed and unpretentious environment - go check it out!~

oPW-LM0pXja0lDwZybXd9g.review_text: "Exactly what sort of theme or aesthetic are they going for here? Neo-gothic Nigerian?" - my out-of-town friend  This is not a casual pint-ing locale.  The decor is ghastly, it's a really tight space, and all the beers have *very* strong flavours.  Also, most of their beers are bottled or canned, not on tap.  Still, it manages to be enjoyable if you go with the right one or two friends, and is probably a good place to "test" a date who claims to be a beer enthusiast.  Points given for its being-hard-to-find-itude.  The sign for this place is just a golden, um, church key, so between that and the fact that this place is so small you'll need to keep your eyes peeled to find it.  More points for actually stocking the beers on its menu, which is more than I can say for other mega-menu beer houses around the country (e.g., Brickskeller and RFD in Washington, D.C.)  Finally, I like that the music you'll hear likely is coming from the iPod of the guy serving your beer.  That always seems to work out pretty nicely.  If you enjoy beer, you'll likely find one here that you like (just don't count on help from the guy behind the bar to find it).

dZclswnuCC3xomr8-Wk3Zw.review_text: First off, the bartender (long haired blonde guy) is a beer NINJA. He opens bottles with such precision and keeps his bar so clean, it is amazing. Second, he knows anything and everything you need to know about his selection. He even gave my gf and me a sample, along with himself, of some japanese commemorative ale. If you LOVE beer, you GO HERE!  I forgot to add....if you "check-in" on foursquare, you get 50% off your first beer. Don't be afraid to ask "the beer ninja," he was totally cool with looking at my phone and saying "you checked-in...that's you, right?? It's that easy."

c4bNOJ5XnKKoHJoQE4zrcQ.review_text: Great local dive with fabulous beers! Always ask the bartender their recommendation if you are not sure, she knows her stuff!

NDH7N_TqW7uZPqLBuGTWqA.review_text: low key and cozy.  Good place to enjoy drinks but not get smashed.

0i0r2t1qDdUdxBBRZTzXRQ.review_text: This venue gets five stars from someone who doesn't fancy too many types of beer. The bar tender is very knowledgeable and recommended Dogfish Head Midas Touch Elixir. This is officially my new FAVORITE Beer!!! Thanks!

tvuGWTCPKe4fu5NOMTxGlQ.review_text: Awesome place. Great beer. Cool folks.  We went on an off night, just to check it out and ended up staying for a few beers. The small crowd at the bar was really friendly and the bar staff was knowledgeable and welcoming.

wUHRkLuCyEYz4AXURA2RbQ.review_text: We were looking for a great lounge to sit and drink some beer while it rained. We saw this on Yelp and decided to stop by. It was our group and one other couple (it was 4pm so it was a little early) and we sat at the bar and read through the extensive beer and wine list. The guys in the group were impressed with the selection of beers available and loved their choices. I ordered a Baltic Porter that was delicious. The bartender seemed knowledgeable but was very laid-back and hipster. It was a great, quiet place to stop in a get a beer.

r9h5k6keLFuFzhzWgn8x5w.review_text: As a beer lover, I was excited to try Church Key but I found their beer selection only OK, prices to be pretty aggressive, and the space has an odd layout which lacks ventilation.   There are better beer bars in town. For instance, La Trappe is nearby on Greenwich St and has better beer, food, and cooler space. So I'm not sure why you'd choose Church Key.

mSxHHZ9XifErXXFHvVaFew.review_text: Great beers. Great bar. Great bartenders (and staff in general).    Great belgian style quadrupel? check (netherlands something) Great porter? check (something from denmark) Great IPA? check (dogfish head 90 minute IPA) Great belgian? check (hommel) Great light flavor? check (affligem) Great beer? check (De Proef Reserve Signature Ale Collaboration with Port Brewing)  I picked a couple myself, then just asked the bartender and server for recommendations based on styles I was in the mood for.  They hit a home run every time.  100% A+ positive.  Also, they have 4505 chicharrones.  Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.

kogGss_XELN7P0ivFk721g.review_text: This is where my b/f and I decided to ring in our New Year!  We both wanted to be in the city but at somewhere totally mellow.  Church Key was the perfect spot for that.  This place is for the beer lover (although they have some lighter and fruitier beers that will make non-beer drinkers happy).  The pricing was really reasonable and the bartender was a really awesome guy.  It's super small and two floors but a really rich red color and hidden enough that you may miss it.  So happy that we went here and started this year off right!

W82cYXhC2_Rm1IFpGGW8Pg.review_text: We stopped by this place during the soft opening months ago, and I've been meaning to write a review....  Amazing beer list. A little pricey, but you don't come to get drunk, you come to try new and tasty beers. The bartenders are knowledgeable and super friendly and if you have questions or don't know what to order they are wonderful.  If you have a few extra bucks the beer champagne is like butter. You can split a bottle between 4 people. Try it!!

B4cJvWuf59j7XlTdexnVZw.review_text: Cool place with a nice beer selection and good spot for getting away from some of the madness that other places in the area turn into since it's a bit lesser known.  Nice upstairs.  Clean bathroom, though no paper towels when I was in there last.

newGLjBSOkoj-SEj4CZ6qw.review_text: Holy sugar smacks, this place is awesome! My fiance brought me here on a date and I had this deeeeeelicious beer called the Duchess de Bourgeone. It tastes like...well, I can't entirely describe it, but, it's tasty as all get out! My man had this coconut flavored ale, which I stole a sip of and that one was amazing too. The mood everytime i go in is way relaxed and the locals are friendly. Plus the beers are all reasonably priced.  If you want to try some great beers at great prices, give this place the old college try. They have a trivia night going now on Tuesdays which seems like an awesome time to give the place a go. (I also hear that the trivia mistress is easy on the eyes.)

Dk5EPbo1T7F6YA-S2_ZOiw.review_text: I am not a huge drinker, but if I were an alcoholic, this would be my bar of choice. I've been multiple times and every time we end up in epic battles of who can order the most ridiculous beer.  They have 7 pages of beer.  7 PAGES. That is crazy.    its hidden farther down on Grant, so, its usually not too crowded.  You're pretty much guaranteed to find a spot upstairs to have a quiet moment admiring the art on your beer bottle or wondering why they have 1 small mirror on the ceiling.  Once you've had one too many, you can mosey down to golden boy or any of the other late night joints in the hood to soak it all up.

WRdXMEGqq1YzmjmwSJ-T-w.review_text: "Hey!  It's 11:45pm.  You all need to get out in 15 minutes!"  Umm, I do?  Why?  Oh, you close at midnight.  Hmm. Ok.  Buzz kill.

DICLJDdq0HpvOVYR5mB4gA.review_text: Great laid-back spot for a couple beers with friends.  Their biggest strength is the extensive selection of Belgian ales and other European brews as the interior is nothing to write home about.

sEUgANQTEUKFjlhEZiOcLQ.review_text: Finding a bar with character is actually tougher than it sounds. Don't be fooled by the rest of the bars you've been to. It takes something real special.  Church Key only sells beer, and for good reason. It's a damn cool bar where you can find all sorts of beers you've never heard of and people smart enough to get you something you'll like.   The first time I went there (I'm a regular now) I was intimidated by the number of beers they have available, and they have some cheap stuff if you just want a 2 dollar beer too. The staff are ALWAYS super down to earth, mellow and can talk beer like it was their first born child.   They have a nifty second floor and if you have a big group you can go up there. I like the decor, it's slightly darker with an unassuming appearance.   I highly recommend checking it out and I'm fairly certain you'll be a convert. Cheers and I'll catch you in my favorite bar in the city.

6cRPIeOU1HJK19C7Cpx68Q.review_text: This is a hidden gem in North Beach. Good luck even finding it because it is nicely tucked away between stores on Grant Street. When you do find it, however, you'll find a great little dive with plenty of beers to choose from. The taps are constantly rotating, so you can always have something new to enjoy.

HEPfqAH6ObF36Fp1B9Fi1Q.review_text: Awesome joint if you love beer, which unfortunately (since it's so bad from a slimming-down perspective), I do. The menu is overwhelming, and reminded me a bit of the menu at "Falling Rock Tap House" in Denver, or maybe "The Brickskeller" in Washington D.C., but the ambiance is unique and cool as well.   It's a small, intimate bar, with an awesome bar tender and cool tunes. I say awesome bar tender, because I was on vocal rest and he gave me a book of old, recycled beer menus for my new notepad. Stellar!  As for the beer, I tried the "Aventinus" at the suggestion of my pal Aaron, and loved it. Highly recommend it, and I'll definitely be returning in the near future.

HQvlXqSeRF3nhAnZw2IL8g.review_text: One of the best beer bars in all of SF. Just plain awsome. Huge beer list.

v3Fm96Fm6oe0YpoHPUPZ-A.review_text: This place is for beer connoissuers. It's a very specific niche that they are going for, and it works incredibly well. Go to this bar if you want one thing, and one thing only: a really unusual beer that you can't get anywhere else.  If you are the kind of person that likes to talk about the subtleties of a beer for ten minutes, then this is your heaven. I must say that I am not that kind of person, but after drinking two of the beers, which had 9% alcohol content, I was happily drunk and ready to spend the rest of my life here.  This place is great. Beer lovers, the Church Key should be at the top of your list.

hrWnftKtSg5kOlMkMUW0cQ.review_text: I came to Church Key on a Thursday night for some beers.  They play some freaky ass weird music here, but I still dig it.  Great selection of beers that the hipster bartender that is way, way too cool for you will sort of help you navigate through.  They've got seats around the bar and a couple of tables and a couch with a table on top of kegs in the front.  Very small intimate place, it's funky and very San Francisco.  I dig it and would come back again.     FYI the beers are highly alcoholic.  I wish someone carried me to the next bar, but alas, I had to walk.

Lr-B-r-KF80yFy-2u336bw.review_text: It was a warm night in North Beach tonight . There were a lot of beautiful people roaming North Beach. Church Key was one of our stops. They have a good selection of beers on Tap . My companion and I had a few . I was digging on the DJ he was spinning old school 45s and dance music . The place was a packed house .There were a lot of attractive women there. The only marking outside was a Key on a sign.

4pzr6KuS85859EICMI7MDw.review_text: Jason, you have outdone yourself again!  While it's still in its opening and final remodeling phases, the Church Key brings to an all-around wacky and wild neighborhood is a solid delivery of pints with a punch. I'm talking about beer, folks, and lots of it.  You can find brews from all around the world, eight on tap, and scores upon scores by the bottle. There's wine, too, but I want to conquer CK's beer menu before I embark upon the fantastic ports. Note, beer and wine ONLY. But really, with such a great selection, why would you want anything else?  Jason is so friendly and knows his stuff, too. Totally a different vibe from the Broken Record. I already love it just as much.  Formerly an aspiring trendy soju lounge, I think this is a major upgrade. It's now the ultimate CHILL and intimate place to go for a nice brew with friends or a special someone. Oh yeah, oatmeal stout head 'staches are HOT.

2nBPGg56am7XoOdGR4tofg.review_text: I really like this place. It's perfect for when you're in the mood to drink a couple of beers and unwind with friends, but aren't really up to Going Out and stumbling your way back home in the wee hours of the morning (a different yelp review for another time). I usually come here when I want to grab a drink or two with a friend or a small group of people, but wouldn't really recommend going here if you're with a large group because it isn't huge and seating is somewhat limited. The beer list is LONG, so if you plan to come here with someone who "doesn't like beer" there is probably something on the menu even for these foolish people. The bartenders also let you sample the beers on draft, which helps you avoid the disappointment that comes with spending $9 on a beer you thought you would like but actually makes you want to gag. Ok, I haven't actually had a beer that makes me feel like that, but I could imagine. The bartenders I've encountered here have been pretty knowledgeable and helpful, so I've only gotten good suggestions so far. I just came here again this past weekend when a friend was in town, and he was both impressed by the local feel of the place and happy to see an obscure beer he loves on the menu (which made me look cool). It is definitely worth trying sometime!

opSbHEfHYfCZvfff7vKvYA.review_text: My friends and I started our night out in North Beach at Church Key. We arrived around 930/945pm and the bar was pretty busy. There was 1 bartender at the time, so we waited a couple minutes to be served, which was fine, since they had a long menu of beers to choose from. The menu was printed on about 4 8 1/2 x 11 paper stapled together..nice and simple, but the text was kind of small, so it was a little hard to read under the dark lighting. Once we had our beers, we sat upstairs where there was ample seating to enjoy the drinks and talk it up a bit. Church Key was probably the only bar we went to where we could have a decent conversation without having to yell at each other. Of note..this place does not have a full bar..beers only, but I can dig it.

LdeYSL_KsoilCqj7HJsWDQ.review_text: my companion arrived about 10 minutes before I did. all the chairs along the bar were full so she sat at the closest table.  when I arrived, the bar stools had cleared out and we took two.  the menu is quite impressive.  but...... at $7 to $9 a glass, I would really like a bartender to have some input - other than to say that they are good. how about offering samples?  and my friend was a bit put off that he hadn't acknowledged her before I got there.  the music was horrible.  we moved on.

b_UoSaXEdNQIYnx1K9eqaQ.review_text: Let's start by saying I know nothing of beer haha I only know I like drinking it, and this is a great place for the drinking of beer.  1. It has A LOT of options, that come in all different sizes ;) 2. It has a second floor with a nice sofa space, and there is usually space for a big group. 3. It is super close to many different food places (lots of pizza!)  That's about it, have nothing else to add.  Check it out, it's great!

hzJpuehCf7OR_UwEB9O5xw.review_text: Great beer selection!  And the staff is very nice and helpful as well.  It's a small place but they do have an upstairs lounge area.  Probably wouldn't bring a big group there but for a date or just a few friends, it's the spot to go.

LEho8AFSA-H6M9SekKxb_A.review_text: Definitely a tad different from the normal bars in North Beach, where you can walk in with shorts and flip flops.   Church Key is a little on the fancier side. Nice plush couches and cute little bar stools for people to hang out and chat. Dim lighting and no smelly BO that you might find in the bar across the street (ahem... Green and Grant!).   This place is all about beer! No cocktails, and their wine selection consisted of 4 different things.... a Merlot, a Pinot Noir, a Chardonnay, and a Pinot Grigio. The beer selection, on the other hand, consisted of a booklet. The waitress we had was extremely helpful too. Very knowledgeable. Picked a great beer called Pranqster that tasted like a Blue Moon.   Cute little bar. I like it!

5_kcuB0zrG3guGlBOcW-JA.review_text: Great little North Beach bar with a solid beer selection. Lots of bottles, all quality. Good stuff on tap too if you're a brew geek. The night I was there they were running out of quite a few things but its a very enjoyable spot!

9XamBJ9gDGlpK3-0djd0UA.review_text: Great atmosphere, great location, great libations, and friendly bartender. I'm gearing up to be a regular.

cCPjASKs5YpMB4BmN2oSZg.review_text: Very good beer selection and good service but the death metal was playing very loudly. Also, the bar was empty when my gf and I first entered, because the bartender was smoking on the sidewalk with his friends.   Keep in mind, this was a Friday night, not an off night. The small crowd, even for a small space, was surprising.

ILz8ApVEgTqbv5LnC6PyuA.review_text: I understand the need for friends of the establishment in question to give rave reviews, but I'm just gonna be honest. Definitely a quality beer menu with some nice items on tap. The whitbier I tried was good and refreshing. The seating still remains a problem though, not enough downstairs. Upstairs has a lot more space, but it just felt like a weird lounge and not so much a bar where you'd go drink good beer. I have a feeling the guy to girl ratio will be extremely high, as the girls I came in with didn't seem too impressed. Oh well, the beer is definitely the attraction here. I'll definitely be back for some more beer tastings and hopefully for the wild game pies once they are cookin...

-g3XIcCb2b-BD0QBCcq2Sw.review_text: Popped into Church Key for a quick drink while waiting for a table at Tony's Pizza down the street.  I had been here once time before when it was a tad more crowded and ventured into their upstairs area.  This time around, we parked ourselves in the back corner away from the door/draft.  Their beer selection was impressive, and I enjoyed the off the wall decor and characters that were seen hanging out at the bar.  The place seems to have a lot of locals and usuals, so this was a great place to chill out and steer away from the more bro-ish places on Grant.  Definitely stop in here for an eclectic beer collection (and be prepared for strange looks when you want to order wine - ain't nobody got time for that at Church Key).

FJFt4-W5UNeqF1r9vOklvw.review_text: Great place to stop. Bar-tendress is very knowledgeable and helpful with great recommendations. Not crowded and quick service.  Great place

YdbvKA27AazwRdIY-FRbWw.review_text: I am so late in writing this review. This place is so friggin awesome.  One of my favorite things to do in SF is host networking mixers, and Church Key was one of the best ever.  I'm a bit of a beer fan, so when I saw Lost Abbey's Serpent Stout on tap, I knew that we'd found the right place. Extremely knowledgeable bartenders, lots of rare ridiculousness, appropriate glassware and friendly folks.  Also, they had the Black Keys album on repeat. *WIN*!!!  The place is a little small, but it's cozy. Upstairs has a low ceiling, which, at first, was oppressive, but after a few beers, it kicked ass. One caveat, which doesn't matter so much during the winter months, but during the summer it gets hotter than a supermodel in a Microbikini. Like, literally uncomfortable. Other than that the setting is great.  They have a pretty quick rotation of kegs, and their website is inaccurate. Just go there, ask them what's best and drink away. You won't leave disappointed.  TL;DR: AWESOME Beer bar, right up there with Toronado, but a little smaller.

N67UV9tXgKEqFINl1P2kQg.review_text: I liked the relaxed environment of a Sunday evening at Church Key. Had a deliscious cherry beer while waiting for our table at Cafe Jacqueline.

_SVAW_bwFx3G2tDqmsmOBw.review_text: Church Key is a great name for a bar.  Unfortunately I'm not really into going to church these days.  It's always good to find another place that has a devotion to providing a good variety of interesting international and local beers to the masses.  I had two draft beers while here; Hacker-Psorr Helles and Allagash Black.  Both were delicious and I have tasted neither one before.  There were a few other options available in addition to a healthy selection of bottles.  Unfortunately i have to give the three stars based solely on those pluses.  The bar area is awkward; if you're not sitting at the actual bar, you're in a weird position because the one bathroom is at the end of the walk space behind the bar seats.  So it's nice to be close to the bar but be ready to move a lot.  Other than that the rest of the place looks like a cheap lounge not to mention there was an insanely overpowering smell of bleach emanating through the place.  The candle light was a little cheesy and the place definitely doesn't have the feel of your average beer bar (maybe that's a good thing for some people?).  The prices on some of the bottles were a little ridiculous too.  I know that the Schneider-Brooklyn Brewery collaboration brew called Hopfen Weiss is somewhat limited, but i thought it was ridiculous to see it going for $16 a bottle when I've seen it for $8 at other places.  It kind of makes me think the place cares more about seducing chumps too drunk to know better (well, it is North Beach) than actually sharing a love of beer with the rest of us.  The one saving grace is that while I choose to mostly dodge North Beach, if you want to meet in a bar somewhere in the area, I would make it be this one.  The place wasn't packed like a sardine tin and the clientele seem to be mostly enjoying themselves at a moderate pace instead of trying to get completely obliterated.  Just don't try to get me back across Green St. now...

mAhty2OHDTtLm00quB5Xjw.review_text: Upstairs loft is a good place to get artisanal beer with friends.

Cfo08zrATMf9m9Qh1UtcXA.review_text: Since long time i wanted to come and enjoy some beers in Church Key and i finally did it tonight.   It is located at bars strip of North Beach along with others. Have much better selection of beers. Most of them in bottles which i prefer and not more than ten top.  Sadly there is a problem with Church Key; it  just does not feel like a beer joint, there is no beer character.  Yes they have some selection of beers but sadly they can be enjoyed at a better environment.

kcYMw-UIj7naRMuCstTQqg.review_text: Generally I like this place. Especially when they played some Gojira on the bar stereo.   My gripe is that the bartender on 12/30/10 was acting shady. I ordered a peach beer of some brand. The bartender gave me different beer of the same brand, which was my fault because I named the brand only and not the variety. He offered to take the beer back and give me the one I wanted, but I relented and accepted the beer he had already poured; he insisted that I was getting a good deal on the beer. I took the beer back to my table and checked the menu to see what I had gotten, and it seemed that I had been overcharged by $1. I decided not to bring it up cause I had already left the bar area.  The second time I ordered a round I checked the menu and added up the expected total in my head. I gave the barkeep my order and he checked the menu on his own to get the correct prices, but the amount he told me overcharged $2 for the round. I pointed this out on the menu and he apologized and charged me the correct amount.   The lesson is this: Go to this bar, be prepared to pay a premium for good beer, and definitely double-check your bill like you're getting Chinese take-out.

gFB-b7IeNR3leLq8q-qeGQ.review_text: OK, so I get the "Key" part of Church Key... there's a picture of a key above the doorway.  But where's the "Church" symbol?  Maybe put a cross on the key or something?  Curious.  Anyhow, Church Key is a pretty solid place.  The beer selection is quite nice... my friend was pleasantly surprised he was able to find a couple of his favorite beers.  It was a tad crowded along the bar area for our group (there were 8 of us), but it felt cozy and warm.  The bartender let us bring food in to munch on while we drank... bonus points for that.  He was laid back and let folks sample a bit of his beer recommendation before they committed.  All-in-all, a great place to have a drink and hang out with friends.  It never got too crowded on a Friday night, but it never felt dead either.  C harming H uge beer selection U pstairs area with more room R estroom a tad hard to get to at the back of the bar C ozy downstairs H as a picture of a key instead of a sign outside  K ind bartender willing to let you sample first E veryone will find a beer they like Y ou should go!

OpzqHzqod7FZusRzin5KRg.review_text: Surly bartender.  Expensive beers at $7 for 12-14 oz drafts.  Beer choice was lacking.  Both the Columbus Cafe (around the corner on Green St) or Kennedy's (down Columbus Ave) have far broader beer selection, and much better attitude to customers.  We would not visit Church Key again.

IQymtwcSb7elorFDr_6YUQ.review_text: I'm not a huge fan of this spot. I am a huge fan of beer but I can't afford anything on the menu! The beers basically start at $7 and go up to $50. When I went the place was dead which can be a good things if that's what you're into, we were the only ones in there which was not what we were looking for at the time. I do give them some props for playing pretty good music off real LPs. I may go back but unlikely.

bIt7A8ooqfjvP-2SQ_RUFw.review_text: It's a nifty little spot with a low-key vibe.  A sophisticated yet simple addition to Grant, I went in wanting to like it.  And I did.  But there were a few things that were off key at Church Key.   The first was the douchetastity of the clientele.  Certainly not the bar's fault, so I do not deduct stars for that.  But can we devise some kind of  busing program for overachievers?  Like they did that time with the homeless before the Democratic convention?  Just once, I'd like to sit on a barstool next to a plumber or a poet or a vet tech in the north side of town.  Because when it's nighttime and I hear things like "ROI" and "synergy" shouted in my ear, I get depressed.  My city's been hijacked, and I'd like it back.  But more importantly, Church Key served me hot wine.  Twice.  Even though I ordered two different kinds, in an attempt to avoid the nosehair-searing, eye-watering experience of the first glass.  I think the wine was sitting under a hot light or stuffed in the bartender's pants before we got there.   It's partly my fault for not saying anything, but the bartender was already annoyed because the Mr. had the audacity to ask him about the beers.  Not like, "Why don't you carry Bud?" but simply, "Do you have a pilsner?"  I guess our not knowing which of the selections was a pilsner was bothersome to our expert bartender, the server of hot wine.   So I think I'd really dig this place if they'd move the wine and check the 'tude.

LkdzvgX0V4yn5MKscJ4j6Q.review_text: Ehhh. Was not that impressed with this place. We were staying at a hotel nearby, so decided to stop here for drinks based on the reviews. Beer selection was good and the menu is kind of hilarious (skip to the wine selection and have a giggle). Other than that it's super tiny and I could do without the pretentious hipsters.

1DAzZPdaN78njTKhbC1JFg.review_text: Have I told you lately that I love you? Over the past year ChurchKey has become my go-to bar in SF -- it has NEVER disappointed, even when it was completely crowded during the North Beach festival. The beers are FANTASTIC -- completely diverse, always changing and never dull.  I happened upon trivia night recently when I was out with a group of friends -- and it was great. Good crowd, good service, great beer. Well done CKey.

b0lXNnfnZpKPv7xNwpG3Ig.review_text: The bartender is so, so nice here.

xNIFzp7I9v6XEkIgjvavEA.review_text: This bar is great. Nice and small, great range of beer, chilled out music, and friendly people. Feels good.

mOCM896HwdM4sL961RRNHg.review_text: I guess I would say that this is the closest thing I have to a neighborhood bar. Keep in mind however that I have a hard time staying in my neighborhood to hang out. When I do however, decide to stay in the North beach/russian hill-ish area, I love to start by getting a slice down the street then stop by here for a couple well selected beers.   Go ahead and ask the bartender questions about the selection. He has opinions and will ask you questions back to find out exactly what you want. This place also has a fair amount of regulars who are cool and appreciate good beer. With all of the beers on the menu here both in bottle and on tap, I find it so funny that they have PBR on the menu as their "mystery american beer". You can usually make a pretty accurate character assessment of a person at the bar if they passed up all of the awesome options for a PBR (im just sayin).   One strange feature of this place is the placement of the washroom. It is just passed the bar where there is a very narrow place to line up. This means that people waiting for a chance to relive themselves are inevitably standing right next to a group who is having a conversation at the bar. This oddly enough leads to some interesting new conversation dimensions.

t9OAdJcdL3suwm0jsAzQEw.review_text: Super chill North Street bar that is a bit off the main drag (Columbus). Come here if you're looking for a relaxing place to enjoy a beer without having to deal w/ obnoxious clubbers and pushy Marina-types. Their beer list is extensive, and you better believe that the bartender knows his stuff because the only thing they serve is beer.   Random aside: First listing on the beer menu is the "American Mystery Beer" which can be anything from PBR or Natural Ice to something that actually tastes like beer!  Samples for $1 if you're not sure what you want.

w6SaPljfM2KfW9guNXCkGA.review_text: I have been really feeling this place lately. Went on Monday. Back again on Wednesday. It is the perfect spot to meet a friend or two for a relaxed drink and some catch-up conversation. Doesn't hurt that all i have to do to get there is basically roll down the hill from my apartment. To motivate me for the climb back up I stop and get a slice at N. Beach pizza.   Monday night there was no DJ and about 5 regulars posted up at the bar. Other than that, my friends and I (loving the big booth in the window) were the only people there. It still had a great vibe though. Drank Alagash White all night. Yumm.   Then went back last night (wednesday night) and it was definitely more full. There was a DJ but my friend and I were still able to talk without shouting. We sat upstairs in a nice quiet corner. This time I couldn't resist the PBR light in a PBR chalice. Just fun.   Might go back tonight. Too early to tell...

lhvKgF5nrS9B5j2FUbxRhw.review_text: I was never much of a beer drinker until I moved in with my current roommate. He introduced me to higher quality beers than what you normally find at your typical bar or restaurant.  These beers are not the cheap college-drinking brew you pick up from 7-11 or Safeway and pound when you get home.  These are ones which provoke your palette like wine does. This is what Church Key is all about.  A few to try out if you are not much of a beer drinker but are looking to explore:  Tripel Karmeliet (which was on tap when I last visited) is a sweet Belgian beer.  The Chocolate Cherry Stout is also a great choice for those who have a sweet tooth.  Church Key has a very extensive menu which is always changing.    There's room upstairs to sit and hang out with your friends.  It's fairly low key and not very noisy so you can actually carry a conversation.  The only thing I don't like is that it last call is at 11:30pm.  However it is close to Grant and Green, Maggie McGarry's, etc., so Church Key is a great place to start your night in North Beach.

q0HDybhT0V9dXrs63_WqWQ.review_text: At first sight, you'd think this was just another little casual bar like the millions of others trying to stand out in the city. Church Key is definitely a bit unique. Their beer selection was fantastic, to be honest. The Allagash Witbier is phenomenal, a mild yet well-rounded flavored beer. The beer menu alone was about the same size as a Cheesecake Factory menu, which is impressive.  As Phil H. said, the trivia questions were tough and I applaud the Hipster Holiday Sweater team for apparently knocking it out of the park! I had no idea Ronald Reagan had cheated on an eye exam just to get accepted into the cavalry (I believe that's what the question was).  Not a big fan of the bathroom being at the front (or back) of the bar, where you have to climb over adamant trivia-knowing locals; everyone staring at you as you patiently wait for the person inside to hurry the hell up (yes, you look fine, plus everyone's drunk already).  I would love to come back with a team of ass-kicking trivia players though.

vLyk1ugUbbX_wj-gPysizQ.review_text: Great beer.  Bad ambience.  Worse service.  We came in about 1130pm to have a beer.  Bartender was rude when we asked about the menu.  Then she walked away for a while.  Eventually we got our drinks.  Beer was undeniably excellent.  Short while later another guy grabbed the mic and announced that everybody needed to "get the f*** out" by 12 o'clock sharp.  Overall vibe was one of drinking in somebody's unkempt apartment.  Somebody who did not want you in their apartment.  If I wanted to be treated rudely, I'd go to work.  I'll not go back to Church Key.  Next time I'll drink expensive beer at home, where the bar is clean, the people are more friendly, and I'm seldom told to "get the f*** out".

iI5hC_uNUBGkkvtWrBIaZQ.review_text: Fun little bar if you like good beers and want to spend a bit of money enjoying random beers ranging from $6-$50.    They even have the "American Beer Surprise" for $2 - which randomly gives you Mickey's, High Life, or PBR.  This is basically the best surprise ever, because no matter what you get, you always win.  The place is your average thin, two story dim loungey style place (like Jade, Mr. Smiths, Duplex, etc.).  In fact, the bar area is really narrow - you end up brushing against every beer enthusiast's backfat on your way to the bathroom.

_nDLZ65hEbo6xjvj5MR46g.review_text: I went there too just relax after a hard day in the pit, the beer is cold and the ladies our hot, the bartender is nice and the well drinks out strong, just a place to kick back and forget your problems.

Z-crhxj5qLhPIRiGwE8D7g.review_text: I was really disappointed in this place. The bartender was really slow, impersonal, and seemed annoyed he had to serve me instead of talk to the girl down the bar (the only other customer in the bar). I've bartended for years and usually I'm understanding but this place just seems snobby and too hip. Its also way over priced. This place is over-hyped for sure.

BwTPj8XS_iqdSTLPBVMs1w.review_text: We walked down to Church Key after spending some time at Savoy. When we asked the bartender for something nice like a beer or something, he rudely stated that it was all he served there. Sorry buddy...didn't know that. It was our first time there. Anyway, water under the bridge. He gave us a nice bottle of some Belgium beer and another bottle of beer that we enjoyed. Hipster place. Not loud or full of annoying drunks. Good place for a chill mello night out.

WaQ7KcZd3wVozXiDFWIDVA.review_text: This bar has nice decor.  It has a huge list of beers.  I'm a wine drinker, and they only had one choice of white wine, which I drank.  It was actually nice to have no choice on what to drink, for once.

UdnFa74MR3BIHFoN_tsLwA.review_text: Stopped in during my trip from Boston and was really impressed with the beer menu at this place. Nice selection of various Belgian brews, although it tends to be biased towards the bottles quite a bit.   The bartender is absolutely great and knows his stuff big time. If you've been looking for a place to gulp down quality beer and converse with a bartender who's being paid because he knows his stuff and isn't a pretty face try this place out.   Anyone shocked by the prices needs to do some research on what these beers cost at a liquor store before you pass judgment. Good beers are not exactly cheap. Not to mention the alcohol volume in many is that of two standard beers like many of you are used to.   Good people, cozy bar (pretty small) and a small upstairs area. Give it a try, but stay away if you like loud music, dance floors and guzzling Bud Light.

KTs38V5KZE7HLoSaq1vrKw.review_text: I dig this place. The beer selection alone is what makes it a solid in my book. Good beer is easy to find. Unique, great beers on tap are HARD to find and this place has 'em. The beers are kinda pricey - it's true, but I don't know...even Whole Foods has beers that are $15+ a bottle...at least here I get served a glass and can send the beer back if I don't like it.

T1onvez6kj1aKChjFQCTOQ.review_text: Scenario: A random Saturday night out with friends, one of which seemingly knows every bar in the city.  Product: Unique beers and wines you probably don't know (and soon meat pies from a chef!). For example, there was everything from an oatmeal stout to local wine to a sparkling wine in a can. No joke, surprisingly good stuff.  If you're going to pay $6-7 for a beer, come here and get something unique and well-crafted.  Service: Jason, the owner was tending and doing a wonderful job of serving the dozen or more of us in a timely fashion and giving everyone some personal attention. He was even cool with us bringing in pizza, though I expect you won't need to once the meat pies start arriving.  Atmosphere: This place is new so still unknown. The menu is unique, constantly changing, and very descriptive. The snozzberry beer tasted like snozzberries, whodathunkit. OK, it was blueberry, still delic.  As clean cut as the place is and as knowledgeable as Jason is, there is no sense of pretentiousness.  Uniquity: Chill place, great owner/tender, unique drinks, fair prices and the right 'hood make this the place to be. I almost don't want to yelp this so it can stay a secret from the 4-collar popping types.

ZBLZIOrO3DZJzDFlFO-bJw.review_text: Didn't mean to stumble into this place, but after roaming north beach need a not-so-crowded place to have a drink.   Church Key was a cozy little space with a small bar, a hilarious bartender and a nice loft space upstairs.   It's a great place to come with a small group of friends and take over the upstairs area.   I don't know what the bartender's name was, but he cracked me up.   Line of the night at closing time: Get out unless you're bangin' the bartender! hahahaha.   I'd definitely go back for their unique selection of beer. I'm not a beer connoisseur by any means so I was pleasantly overwhelmed by the 10+ page menu of beers.

rWad0m47ODrKbYh50TNk3A.review_text: Church Key is one of those bars that has a good combination of modern style and local charm.  The latter quality comes in the form of the really down to earth staff.    I patronized Church Key rather early in the evening, and found the vibe to be really laid back.  The staff were patient and conversational... offering some good suggestions on beers and wines available.  The prices are nominal for a bar of its caliber, and there are a variety of seating options from an intimate bar, window seats, high tops, and even a more intimate upstairs area with a balcony.    While I didn't sample any mixed drinks... the beer list is rather extensive...and there are some great wine (including sparking wine) selections.  Definitely a classy spot to hit up before or after dinner, if you're looking for good conversation.

nOvi-L-rwaClqfXFW5H_OQ.review_text: love tasty beers -- live around the corner. this place should be my goto -- but i get a bad vibe two times out of three.

c-EMjMBY4uKaxr-s33Q61g.review_text: Cool place, great neighborhood, great beer selection

DJ_pDxBy1L-La_qg8EADnA.review_text: Amen!  The  Church Key has proven my Atheism to be a false doctrine of idolatry indeed!!  Hallelujah!  Rejoice!  For Dionysus has revealed to me on this day that awesome craft brews can in fact come in cans!  I bear not false witness, I swear to it!  I hath seen with my own eyes that aluminum doth not be a barrier to the rich, complex tastes that are most often associated with deep, chilled drafts of the popular proclamation!    There *is* a life in hops that come from Maine!    Colorado *is* more than Anheuser Busch picnic niceties with cool Superbowl commercials!  Go!  Go now to the bar at the base of the T-Hill!  Go and spread the word, the blessings lay in wait for those that can hear...  Live!.

4T2uVlRjkl0eogswfL2bTA.review_text: This place is easy to miss! The dark exterior only has a symbol of a white key above the door.   The interior is dark with a bar at the back and a few tables. There is also an upstairs, but I didn't go up.  The bar has tons of bottled beer as well as 10 rotating taps of locally brewed beer and micro-breweries from across the country. Awesome!   The bartender knew her stuff and was very friendly.   I went on a Wednesday after work, the bar was not too crowded. They also have live music every Wednesday!  I will definitely be heading back

qV7KFRaoWy3oplj8e9rGtg.review_text: There's only beer here. But, they have a big list of beers to choose from.   They are mostly bottled, but it's fun going through the beers and the description for each beer.  Sometimes they have a DJ spinning funk, adding to the nice ambiance of the smallish place.  Grab some friends, grab a couple of beers from the guy wearing glasses behind the bar, and then grab a booth upstairs.  Oh, and say hi to the tattooed girl sitting at the bar.

0E7L58EyWJV5mOC4qxvjXg.review_text: Can one say enough good things about this place, the selection, or the service?   YES, one can. So I'll mention a couple of other particulars that interest me at the time:   -- Cool copper bartop. I saw an apparition there the other night (see photo). It's like chemistry experiment and religious experience all at once.  -- La Folie for sale (like Duchesse de Bourgogne but not so sweet)  -- Mezzanine with mirror on ceiling. It's pretty small, don't go gettin any ideas...

pgHCj7DSqI8NWx7WucnH3w.review_text: Really great beer place in North Beach. HUGE, i mean HUGE selection of unique beer from all over the world.  Beer connoisseurism is on its way up - so this is a great place to expose yourself to all different types of brew if you want to become a beer sommelier, or at least someone who knows a thing or two about beer beyond keystone and natty ice.  Try the Chai Tea Beer - its awesome.

029nDskge0gV-LSw-MYWvw.review_text: Went here with a few friends and we all LOVED it!  Great prices on fantastic wines too!!  Keep up the good work, the great prices and awesome wines and we will be loyal fans!

eAzWJ1Wwky3wGw2kmmT_BQ.review_text: Unbelievable. Been here many times before and liked it, but I won't be back. Feel bad that this is my first negative review, but the bartender "lady" has some serious anger management issues.  I have never been treated this unprofessional and rude. The worst bar experience I had by far in the 7 years I live in this city. Still stunned...  What happened? We got a bottle of white wine for our group. It was the worst wine I drank in a very long time but OK, it's a beer place and they have lots of good beers there. Guess our own fault. When we (nicely!) asked whether we could exchange the still almost full bottle of wine for a beer or 2 (they sell the same wine by glass also) she suddenly got grumpy. She poured the beers, then made us pay for them and then asked us to leave right after. Just like that. Speechless.  Please dear Church Key, get rid of that bartender. You are a great place otherwise.

kaRMd5xowixbhF6QPYYxKw.review_text: There is only 1 thing wrong with Church Key but it's a big wrong - the prices. The boyfriend and I have each been in San Francisco for over 20 years so it takes some really egregious pricing to shock us but Church Key managed to do it. And in these extremely difficult economic times, I find their prices pretty offensive.   What's sad is that the Church Key has the potential to be one of the most unique, enjoyable bars you could ever have the pleasure of being in.  As the other reviews note, the ambience is very chill:  great lighting, colors, very cozy, and music that adds to the experience but doesn't drown you out.  I never made it upstairs, but down below there is no TV, which is also an  added plus.  My boyfriend and I did not find the bartender particularly friendly, although he wasn't overtly rude, either.  For unusual beer selection, there are a plethora of choices such as City Beer, Healthy Spirits, and Toronado. Or head to Lanesplitters in Oakland, Barclay's in Rockridge, The Warehouse Cafe in Port Costa. While these places not might have the ambiance that Church Key has - their pricing is much more palatable.   If you really want to spend ridiculous amounts of money on beer, go to Mays Field and watch Tim Lincecum pitch, head to the Cliff House for the view, or go the the Top of the Mark for a styley time out.

muPKUHFQnK5_G55k48Avkw.review_text: North Beach pretty much sucks in most aspects. The bars are pretty douche-y, the Italian restaurants are mostly tourist traps, and the parking is just crap. That being said, there are a few bright spots. I personally didn't like the attitude at La Trappe, and well, if you're not into Belgian beer, you're pretty much SOL.   Church Key pretty much takes a teeny weeny little beer/wine space and gives North Beach a mellow little spot with a great beer lineup. The bartenders are nice guys, and the lineup is ever-changing. Are there beers with bigger selections, rarer beers and lower prices? Sure, but not in North Beach, and not with the "welcome to my living room" atmosphere of Church Key. There's a big resurgence in quality and craft beer in San Francisco, and it's always good to see more places pushing the word of good beer.

6AlZdIUJCy-zAp0AG9NXAQ.review_text: Awesome beer selection!  If you have friends who are into beer this is place to be.  It is a small cozy spot so it is perfect if there are only a few people in your group.

bk3LC4qjyk3VEVtpP4P68w.review_text: This is a good bar to find when you finished an amazingly filling dinner in north beach but you either don't want your date to end or you just don't feel like making the treck back to your neighborhood quite yet...after all its a friday night. you didn't blow dry and curl your hair to turn in early...  or maybe its both, and that was my situation...the place is dark, small, apparently theres an upstairs that I didn't see it...for a friday night the crowd was kind of perfect, enough people to feel social but not so many that we couldn't get a seat.  we saddled up to the bar and began looking at a very decent beer menu.  of course the one sour beer I wanted to try they did not have.  And he made it worse by telling me how much i would have loved it had they had it...thanks dude...  luckily our choices were both yummy and i'll will probably be back...for sure

BupxMA1KZEV08MHfBD1EuQ.review_text: so difficult to find this place with no sign at the door. just the key  logo.  and buzz  after try drink after drink and different bars over the area. well. its too bad only beer and wine  anyway. we had super aswesome time.    the bartender from this bar is  muy buena onda.

9nG4nzUjOQ4vLCiFok2_1A.review_text: First off, if it wasn't for Yelper's I would have never visited this place, so THANK YOU!!!   I love going to cozy and casual bars. Especially, the ones where I can wear jeans and never once feel like I'm under-dressed.   This bar is amazing! I absolutely love it. The beer list is like a book, seriously, it is pages. We ranged from dark beer to light beer. We had 3 different beers each. I thought it was fairly priced however, I stayed cleared of the $15 and plus beers. I would really like to see a beer tasting, that would be awesome! We had the best seat in the house. If you can, get the booth on the first floor (next to the door), it's away from the traffic at the bar and allows you to talk without having to scream. Our server, Lisa, was great. Super friendly and always came to check up on us.   I want to give it 5 stars, but parking was horrible. I had to park about 4 blocks away, but it was well worth the walk.

s3kRi7b8t2sdtYcsMbqlJA.review_text: My first time here. Very friendly service + customers. I think they were mostly Jason's friends/buddies.  They have an upstairs sitting area.  We went around 10pm but it started getting crowded around 11pm.    THEY ONLY SERVE ECLECTIC SELECTION OF BEER AND WINE!

drI9J9xeWephVGlfMC487w.review_text: What a wonderful beer selection! There were too many good choices, so in the end I asked my bartender to recommend something rich and dark. The beer he guided me to was really lovely. It was a chocolate cherry stout from Stone Brewing.  The beer was a deep mahogony color. It's cherry and chocolate flavors were perfectly balanced and the beer had a smooth,clean finish. It was definitely something I would drink again or buy on my own. They also had a rose hibiscus beer in stock that I am awfully fond of. Needless to say, there is a good mix of the offbeat and some of the usual suspects. The tuesdsy night trivia was fun background noise. And, the upstairs area is perfect for a small gathering. Which is terrific comsidering I was there for a birthday. Parking is a  bit of nightmare, so walk or take the bus. Don't forget to build in some time extra time to check out the uber cute boutiques on the block or to have a bite at one of the myriad of restaurants nearby.

r-8eQ28RhnQPJdZXHcTXrw.review_text: When I was seventeen I drank some very good beer I drank some very good beer I purchased with a fake ID  My name was Brian McGee I stayed up listening to Queen When I was seventeen  ---  Got a 750ml bottle of Duvel Triple Hop for $50. This can be had at a store for closer to $25. Pretty standard to charge double at bars/restaurants, but I was still surprised I spent $50 on beer.   Luckily, it was very good beer. Not $50 good though.   Come here for a Mission vibe in North Beach.

gEUrtbRV0VLgwS3Da-CndQ.review_text: I had been trying to find Church Key after it was recommended to me, for weeks!  The fact that I frequent North Beach and had to make multiple attempts to find this place is bogus.   HINT: Look for the TINY white key above a door, the type of sign that anyone who's already had a drink prior to looking for this place will never find.  Other than that the beer selection is solid but pretty pricey. An ideal place for someone not worried about price, only quality. Bring a beer guru here to find more than a few difficult to find brews with completely unique taste.   If I'm spending this much and looking for selection I'll typically stay with Rogue across the street, but the two aren't really comparable.

ICdUj6pw9-GtbKMeqcKQOQ.review_text: Very laid-back and mellow to get some great beer and chill. Come in from the chaos of North Beach weekends and relax. The upstairs loft is very nice. Don't bring big groups. Just not gonna work.

Z8Lv1KMN_EE2WM1bSwo7Ng.review_text: I'm not a bar person.  I prefer restaurants, you can hear people easier, there's less drinking, and more food.... all things I like.  That being said, I really enjoyed my evening last night at the Church Key.  My husband and I got there early, trying to avoid the crowds, sat at the bar and ordered a couple of beers.  I'm also not much of a drinker of beer, but they had this amazing Belgium Apple Beer that tasted much like apple juice, which I now love!  And, my husband who is quite the opposite of me and loves to drink beer, found great beer and was able to talk hops and barely (???) with the very informed and friendly bartender.    Last night they were trying out their food, trying to get the timing right, and so I got to sample their meat pie.  Ox tail and other veggies, and I loved, loved, LOVED it!  If you like beer, meat pies, or tasty apple juice that apparently has alcohol give it a try!

A2mx9xsHoIDNnd81_lxiFA.review_text: Nobody is uptight here, it wasn't very crowded the Friday's night that I went, and the waiters are super friendly. What else can you ask for? Good beer. And they have it. Try the "Double Bastard".

pdilmEaeXuntV4eTnc9KcQ.review_text: I dig this place. Indie rock music and Belgian beers.  And Belgian-inspired beers. Konigshoven quad?  Yes. Maybe a Rochefort? Yes. Taps with other tasty selections?  Yes. Can I walk home? Yes. Is it hard to find because there aren't any words on the sign?  Yes. Beer prices high?  Sure, $7-8 per beer, but you're not ordering coors and bud here.  If you want the watery, cheap stuff, go to one of the touristy bars.  There are plenty. No more questions.

NJkKim1vaowyEKtazPdByw.review_text: The best beer focused bar in SF!  Totally chill atmosphere and friendly staff, both things seriously hard to find in North Beach.    Seriously, they have the best selection which is always changing, and the owner is very knowledgeable and friendly.  Only dock it one star for being so expensive, but that's the price of good beer.  It doesn't stop me from coming here, it only means I order one really good beer instead of 3 mediocre ones.

vi1Ta_3XtGTqkl4p83ZbEQ.review_text: Church Key, I get that you're the "new kid" on the block.  I understand that you have a massive beer selection (as "beer is the new wine").  I also get that you're too cool to have proper signage (prompting me to tell my friends "it's the place with the key outside").  But why did you charge me $51 for a 5 bottled beers?  Don't you think that's a little steep?  Don't you think that's highway robbery?  Nevertheless, I'm sure I will see you at some point again and maybe I'll be in a better mood next time...

rXops73qsJgW91oImt7UJA.review_text: I have the unfortunate distinction of having known Jason King for many, many years.  I knew him when he was a long haired metal head who wore nothing but Pantera and Cannibal Corpse t-shirts.  I was around for his brief and, dare I say, mediocre foray into motorcycle maintenance.  Hell, I even knew him when he lived in a dilapidated squat with trannies, junkies and people so fucking punk rock that having a reasonable conversation with them was impossible.    Yes, I know Jason King, and of all his phases and incarnations his best yet is bar owner.  I mean really, have you been to the Broken Record?  Jason took some shit hole in the Exclesior and made it one of the best bars in the city.  So it is with this in mind that I relate to you the excellence of The Church Key. Sure I can go on and on about how it has high-quality, unique beers you've never heard of from around the world that rotate on a weekly basis.  Or how it has the coolest wall paper I've ever seen (some type of Victorian/Hieronymus Bosch hybrid).  I could even go on about the great local wines or how The Church Key will soon be selling European style meat and veggie pies.  But the best part about this place is that it has been instilled with Jason's trademark unpretentiousness and...well, who am I kidding?  They've got $2 beers!!!!  Woo-hoo!!  Thanks for not being a douchebag Jason!

X9nN47rcS97gHnde2cJf1w.review_text: Church Key is the best thing to happen to North Beach since Italian food.  Unassuming and laid back, this bar welcomes everyone, but luckily much of the crowd walks right by it to Savoy or Grant & Green.  Too mellow for the hard partiers, it welcomes those who want an excellent beer and place to hang out with friends.    The beer is amazing, all hand selected by the owner, Jason.  Props to him, because it's the best beer list i've ever seen at a bar.  Sure, Toronado has more on tap, but not as wide a selection.  There's another bar in North Beach (not going to say the name, but it rhymes with "Tra Lappe") that has more Belgians but is over priced.  I saw a bottle of Kasteel Bruin for $18 there, when Church Key had it for $8 on tap (sadly, not available any longer).  The staff is fantastic, friendly, and tattooed up (the job requires a tattoo on your chest)  and knows their stuff.  The best kept secret in North Beach!!

e1FuiYSV1v29q2OTR9ojBA.review_text: Tucked away on discreet Grant Avenue, a wordless sign with a symbol of an old-fashioned skeleton key hangs over the entrance of this tiny bar.  Formerly Magnet, the new owner has taken the sterile brushed steel interior and warmed it up a bit - gorgeous rich-hued wallpaper along one wall, pressed tin around the bar, Edison bulbs upstairs, and flickering candles...with plans to incorporate more classic touches reminiscent of an old British study or Sherlock Holmes.    This is not your typical North Beach bar.  Church Key's specialty is domestic and imported brews from all over the world - spanning from a microbrew from Escondido, CA, spiced ales, a hibiscus-rose beer, to a $50 bottle of beer called "Lust" that hails from Brasil.  Don't worry - for you non-beer people, there is also wine to choose from, including a careful selection of ports.    The space is quite cozy and good for conversation and lounging.  Since we went on opening night during a holiday weekend, it was very mellow and uncrowded for a Friday (actually, almost all of North Beach was, which is unusual).  Definitely one to watch as an up-and-comer on the North Beach scene...

7oywa3APEn2yb3eGlsr6Xg.review_text: By the way, I just wanted to add Rob to the great staff! Jason has made some really good staffing decisions!

SKEtwR6wa_MUUoNDWLLefg.review_text: Finally, a bar in north beach worth going to...  Sure, the Kerouac fan in me just groaned, but it is true.  North Beach's nightlife has always turned me off.    But the folks at the Church Key are as unpretentious as they come.     The beer list is ridiculous and offers beers impossible to find any where else...   yes, even torando, monk's kettle, and city beer store...     I had a barley wine, Mikkeller's  "Big Bad Barley Wine",  at $22 bucks it is worth sharing with someone just to try.   It was one of the greatest things I have ever put in my mouth.   Taught me how to love again.  Anyway, they have other great beers that are cheaper and come in large format bottles, great to share.  This place is only going to get better, once the old "Magnet" vibe is gone and good people start filling the place.   I really can't wait!!   See you there.

RFuMyqihKYlTKx8SNAjrVw.review_text: I received an explanation from the owner of ChurchKey about the reason why the bartender was so hell-bent on getting us outta there.  They got a shakedown a few weeks ago because some patrons were in there a few minutes past closing.  Liquor Nazis in search of fine money, it sounds like.  I love my City but it really can be just as anti-business as they say.  If a bar can stay open until 6am but stop serving liquor at 2am, then certainly this cool and eclectic little place can last a few minutes past the witching hour.  Patrons who don't want to leave are a sign of a place worth staying.  Thank you to Jason, the owner, for such a polite and courteous email.  I will certainly return to your establishment.

cVgfo9k2D0s-KXtO9MDTPw.review_text: Decided to pay a visit here Saturday night with my roommates after hearing about their awesome beer selection + chill ambiance. Super stoked to experience "the Church Key" and unfortunately, I was let down, not even five minutes into my visit.    Here's what went down in those short five minutes- right as we walk into the door, a man standing outside warned us that the bar just closed and were no longer serving drinks AND that the bartender was a "DB". Since it was only 11PM, I decided to go in and scope out the situation. I walked up to the bar tender who didn't seem very busy and politely tried to get his attention. "Excuse me", I said lightly and got no response from him. Since there were people chatting around me I tried again, but with a little more volume, "Excuse me". He finally decided to make eye contact with me after the 3rd try. "Is the bar closed?" I asked and he shortly answered, "Yes." That was okay, life goes on. As we're walking out, I noticed the bartender was saying something in my direction. Not hearing what he said, I turned around and said to him, "Excuse me?" and he shouted, "But thanks for asking politely..." in a condescending tone. I just walked out, it wasn't worth my time.   Truth be told, the Bartender Saturday night was a "DB".

eAhUW3Lt_V2-LbiaUUcg-Q.review_text: Tried going here twice, the beer list looked decent. Unfortunately, the service wasn't, as they kick out anyone who isn't a regular after about 10:30pm. I never actually got to have a beer here, and I won't go back!

kORGcgi0Iw2RG8gJl84MVA.review_text: They keep it simple and it keeps you unstressed. Great beer selection + my favorite viking bartender!

WfePuaS_iXGNGU6bfDe3JQ.review_text: Beer Stop 23 ---  I walked past Church Key a few times before realizing where the door was. Too funny. Completely nondescript sign with a key above the door that keeps a lot of the riff raff out.  ChurchKey had ten beers on tap of all different variety. They had Santo Marro from DogFish on tap, so that was pretty cool. There was only one bartender but he did a good job of providing recommendations when needed.   Also, no kitchen. You are free to bring in your own food though - plenty of pizza joints around the bar.  Good stop here.

zpmViTr7g_1Ig8jPO0VNSQ.review_text: I've always been a fan of speak-easy type lounges and bars. I don't know what it is about them, but I love to be incognito for awhile and drink my libations in secret. The past few months, I have casually strolled past the Church Key on my way to Savoy Tivoli, or Grant and Green or Gino and Carlo's, or Golden Boy, or...well, you get the picture (this is my 'hood after all), and wondered what the heck it was! The outside is dark, the windows tinted and there isn't any other signage other than a mysterious key hanging over the door. I was dying to know what sort of secretive behaviour was happening behind those doors. Did I need a password? Or better yet, a special key?  Luckily, my intrigue was put to rest last night when my date suggested we check it out for a beer. A-ha! So it's a bar...good to know! We arrived at 7pm, and the place was pretty empty, which was great for us because we could chat and hear one another. We sat at the bar and the bartender was extremely knowledgable on their extensive beer list. I told him I usually drink Stella and wanted something similar. He quickly offered up a Hawaiian Beer that was called "Blonde"-something and had a picture of a hula girl on the front. I'm easy...sold! My date grabbed his favorite German lager and we happily talked and drank our frosty brews for the next hour. We joked around with the bartender and wanted to know what the word was for a beer sommalier. Brewlier? Beerologist? Anyone have answers??  The atmosphere is simple yet cozy and dark. I loved the lounge-y music and low lighting. It appears there is an upstairs loft area to get lost in, but we did not make our way up there. They also claim to have pub quiz on Tuesday nights, so I will have to come back and check it out.  Overall, this is a great place to meet someone for a drink, especially if you are an adventurous beer drinker.
