I think it would be fun to have a large group here as well for some after-work shinanigans.

YVEBucA-FoCaXXXPUpuenA.review_text: Good selection of beer. The bartender was incredibly rude though. My husband asked the bartender to turn down the music a notch because it was so loud that we had to yell to hear each other. It was also hurting my ears. And she said no. WTF? Seriously? What happened to customer service? We would have stayed longer and spent more money but got out of their because my ears were hurting. I regret not taking my tip back. And I will avoid this establishment if that particular bartender is working.

axYXuuUJh4eMW-gsb5jR2Q.review_text: Great bar for beer - if you don't want great beer, don't come here.  The menu is amazing - so detailed and so complete.  The bartenders seem to know their stuff - and are happy to help you if you don't know what you want, most of the time.  The only problem - closes too early: Church Key - why do you close at midnight?

ugHHCgv-MU3mPfSuHBHNlA.review_text: Do not judge a book by its cover. When I first spotted this place, I actually made fun of it out loud for looking like a place that lonely businessmen go to drink alone. That was on a Wednesday. But on a Saturday? The place was packed, and for a good reason. They have an incredible selection of beer and - to my surprise - one by Avery Brewing Co. in Boulder, CO that I had been wanting to try for the past year! The beer selection made our party of 10 beer fans happy, and the duck meat pie was comfort food. I will definitely be back, on a Wednesday or a Saturday or really any day that ends in y.

e21xOMduxvfeXGUOnsLvNA.review_text: I hosted a private event at Church Key on a Sunday afternoon (during a time when the bar is typically closed). The owner Jason was easy to work with, accommodating and made some helpful suggestions. Bartender Stellar was low key and also easy to work with. We had a great time - comfortable setting, wonderful tap list, great space for a smallish gathering. Enough folks were having fun that many people stayed on for hours after the bar opened to the public for normal operating hours. I would without a doubt host there again (and hope to do so). An unpretentious, awesome resource that I'm grateful to have discovered.

kBnQt4jIADaep59-XX0waQ.review_text: error. i have not been to this place

BmipmKVTx37gpfPzK7eU4A.review_text: We dropped into the Church Key this past week on our visit to SF.   What a cool little spot! I would love a place like this in PHX! Small, Dark, no hipsters in sight, nice staff and a HUGE beer selection. Like ridiculous selection.   For sure go check this place out.

vTfoN4FU_wcdX2AKRwb2Hw.review_text: Neato little gastro pub tucked into a quaint street in North Beach. Fantastic beer selection. Amazing range. Super friendly bartender that will help you select. Tried the venison and rabbit sausages and it was great! Cool crowd from the neighborhood.

SPK6XrxnSFxbeY-YLW3Yyg.review_text: This place is stupid good. I love the coziness, and a bartender who not only knew just about everything about every beer on tap, but also was a great conversationalist. The night we went, the music was good, just a nice selection of mash-up mixes and various older dance music playing off a laptop somewhere. I really loved this place, and would definitely go back and recommend to others. Also, fair prices on some delicious drinks. The menu had us laughing, as someone else pointed out. Just read the wine list.

FzJRCkoalWORV9MskE2CuA.review_text: There might not be a Table of Contents for the gazillion beers available, but holy shizznit...!!  TONS of beers/ales from all over, and they're serious heavyweights.  We're talking over 10% A.C. average, some even more potent than wine!  The novella of a menu can make your head spin, but just ask the barkeep for suggestions.  Small space is usually filled with low-key clientele just out to enjoy a few cold ones and shoot the shit.  Only downside is that it can get stuffy, especially on the 2nd floor mezzanine.

nHnNraNUct25HJJTRAGYkA.review_text: Church Key has been bookmarked for a while and I finally made my way there the other night. The joint was dead on a Thursday after work, which meant the bartender could spend plenty of time with us recommending beers. I wanted to test him out by requesting a belgian-style ale that was light and crisp. He first recommended Allegash, which is one of my favorites. But I wanted to try something new so he then suggested Prankster, a northern California brew. Prankster hit the spot and was exactly what I was looking for! Church Key is missing a star because I'm curious to know what the crowd is like on a busy night.

aJbXWA8OuA4mx0B67dXwNw.review_text: I'm so glad Jason opened a spot in North Beach. I love beer, and this kind of spot in the heart of North Beach, with quickly rotating beer menu and a nice laid back atmosphere, is just what the doctor ordered. Yay!

1nJtgBCiMuiRkESt9izaIA.review_text: Nice little spot with 5 or 6 beers on tap. Some bottles as well. I like that you can taste a few beers for $2 each before paying the $6+ for a full beer. It was dead when I went so didn't get to see the atmosphere. The Bartender knew the beer well. I've been before but never reviewed it.

sRQu5rrkNXe5yXjKvPqWrQ.review_text: Perfection! The bar is cozy and chic without being pretentious.  The beer list is really long and has a good variety. The staff is friendly, helpful and fun.  I really love this bar.

BBwqj15pm04Hhm9b3R57bA.review_text: Definitely a cool, comfy place, if a bit hefty for your wallet. Not too pricey for the amazing beer choices, just more than I'd spend on a beer or two if I wasn't planning for this kind of atmosphere. Definitely recommend it.

zTE8KUu2ukFQZ67fZypLtA.review_text: good good beers on tap.  i had an allagash something, don't quite remember exactly what... it's bourbon-based or something like that (i won't even pretend to be an expert on brews, all i know is that's what he said).  it was GOOD.  strong alcohol content, and sweet and fruity.  even better was my friend's denogginizer.  WOW.  trust me, the taste of this beer (i think it was an IPA) was even better than its name.  denogginizer.  love it.   beers on tap range in price from $6 to at least $10.  seems like they have an even bigger selection of bottled beer, but that is something i'll have to check out next time.  the place is small and a bit uppity for a bar, in my opinion.  looks too "loungy", and space is small and there aren't too many places to sit.  not good for big groups.    ladies, the guy-to-girl ratio at this place works in your favor.  i went with my two friends, one guy and one girl.  my female friend and i were the only females on the first floor, in the midst of approximately 15 men scattered about.  just an observation...

bW3HC_sBuEHRvE5FYTYO0A.review_text: You go here to enjoy beer with an intimate group of 2-3. It's quaint for a reason, don't bring a party.   + selection  I would make this my neighborhood bar if I lived nearby.

tFId1_3TcZLzp4lhrjYLWg.review_text: Love love love love LOVE this place.  Classy, laid-back and quiet interior with a friendly bartender and a HUGE selection of beer (it gets pretty overwhelming so I would suggest you ask for recommendations if you don't see something you like right off the bat). This is not a place to rage - it's a place to sit down with a few friends and have a nice conversation. Beer and wine only!  There's a large seating area upstairs with ottomans and couches, so even though the space is small you should be able to find a seat. We invaded the place with a large group of 10+ on a Saturday night and there was enough space for everyone to fit.  There's no sign above the door but keep your eyes peeled for a white key on a black background.

fMpvkGS2D32arEnYSysGOw.review_text: This place blows Le Trappe out of the water for beers and atmosphere.  And there's no douche baggery.  They might also appreciate your yelp review unlike the owner of Le Trappe who thinks anyone that yelps is a complete loser. Support businesses that care! Glad these guys are in the neighborhood.

V9I-TUdXUWtKJkJ3u22gpQ.review_text: Best bar in North beach? Yeah I think so. Look I like a lot of bars. but I like good beer even more... I'm a shit talkin snob when it comes to beer and When I  actually know what I'm talking about. I like to my brothers, friends when they  come into town or even one best friend's mom who loves to go out on the town with me like I'm Billy Dee Williams.... (Ms. C Luv ya). I go to Church key. Damn good Beer selection...Damn good atmosphere.  It ain't cheers and nobody know my name...And quite frankly I don't give damn. But they know what I'm drinking. I love the beer, I love the Bartender and I love the Church Key.  I wish there was a Church Key in my neighborhood....Sniff Sniff

Z3vY6CM1aSJcyDMrFfhPIw.review_text: I really enjoyed this place. I forget the bartenders name, but he is very good. The beer list here is huge and he has the knowledge to properly navigate you through it. The bar itself is quite small so conversation amongst the patrons is common. I didn't head up stairs, but  I assume their is some type of restaurant? If you are looking for a good beer spot, then look no farther, Church Key is it.

EHwNw8KOy8PbkCz46mdhhA.review_text: A nice little bar... a descent selection of high quality beers.  Prices are a bit high, but that is what you get for high quality beers.  Staff are always very helpful.

uZ_y3gL63fJ843L53UW_XA.review_text: I heard about Church Key and had a feeling I would like it.  I am by no means a beer connoisseur, but I enjoy trying new things.  They had more than a large selection of beer I had never tried before, and the setup was quite nice.  We especially enjoyed the loungy (but laid back) feel of upstairs when we had a small group there.  I felt the bartender may have been a little overwhelmed by himself on a Saturday night, but I was won over later in the night with the offering of $2 really cheap cans of beer (I know, not the idea of this place but cheap beer is always good beer in my book).

bCoalme4xOkSseWM63y9jA.review_text: soon after i wrote a yelp complaint, the owner of church key sent me a cordial and earnest letter of apology about my experience.    i really appreciated that.  it's nice to know that a professional and tactful entrepreneur who cares about his customers' opinions owns the joint even though it is *sometimes* (i heard from friends that the other bartenders have always been nice to them) operated by a jack*ss.

yLNVf92fT7e9clI8Vm9e2A.review_text: The only place I've ever had bacon beer...I love the casual vibe, the extensive bottle list and the iconic sign....

SUQk-LIalVZvAO_lVAGR8A.review_text: This is a great bar if you're looking for a low-key atmosphere with a solid ber lineup.  They don't have a huge selection, but every time I've gone in, they've had several beers that I wanted to try out.  I feel like there has been a different bar tender every time that I've been there, but regardless they've all been great.    This is kind of my go to spot when I'm out in North Beach and I want to get away from the crowds and enjoy a beer with a friend or two.

JnGtgOPpkjyWOvWM0SYEXg.review_text: a wet tuesday evening...days and weeks lagging...stroll from south beach to north beach...craft beers at church key...ten ounce deschutes stoic $eight...smooth fruity and easy drinking...seated downstairs at bar...sipping beers and chatting...wooden and great old school bar charm...small, but second floor available...quirky entertaining bartender...taking a fruity pursuit of happiness next for $five...taller glass and easy sweet beer....and, another....black xantus $eight the fourth beer...dark coffee flavor, but surprisingly smooth down...easy sipping beer enjoying with no aftertastes....fifth selection the speedway stout...the least favorite of the beers...dark and fruity, with a medicine aftertaste...not liking, but finishing...three seated at the bar drinking....harolds and kumar evening in north beach...

CU6B8xPsxveZueDewBECXg.review_text: I love hole in the wall type - small bars with low music and good crowds.  This bar is that, and more.  Over 100 beers available?!  Love this.  Great little spot.  I am a new fan.

TEtzbpgA2BFBrC0y0sCbfw.review_text: I'm certain they call this place "Church Key" because it's literally access through the gate of beer heaven.   Rarely crowded, superbly staffed and wonderfully stocked, this beer bar in North Beach is THE go-to place for beer lovers who want a nice space and great prices. There's even something for cheap asses - the "Mystery Beer," a $2 can of PBR or an equivalent. Yeah, it's shitty beer, but it's only $2 when some other bars charge up to $5.   Options, bitches.   For the rest of us, there's a huge menu of great brews, paired with the bartenders' great stories of beer and woe (but mostly beer).

zp3tRNqyeL7-kGDJwMkgpQ.review_text: I just got back from the Church Key, and yeah I'm a major fan.  I looooove beer, and this place has all of my favorites plus some that I have never seen before.  Tonight I had two different beers that were both fabulous and super high in alcohol content.  The first was a spiced beer called Midas Touch which I had never before seen, and the second was one of my old time favorites from Canada, La Fin du Monde.   The beers come to you in the appropriate glass for the type, which is so very cool.  Another reason why I love this place is because the menu tells you everything that you would ever need to know about the beers that they serve.  There is an alcohol content, origin, and description of flavor listed for each.  While the overwhelming amount of beers makes it hard to decide, the menu allows you to decide with some certainty that you will like it.    Besides all of the great beer that they serve, the Church Key has an ultra cool environment.  The lights are turned down low, the giant red lounge bench upstairs longs to be sat on, and the live music just makes you want to stay all night long.  When you stop by, be sure to check out the rad wallpaper when you walk in.

VIIRzZBd7bjTucH637_CcA.review_text: What a great bar! Very kick back, hip, fun. Fair prices, cool people, awesome music.

i1IUqcMBd9DyEgkRoySCkQ.review_text: Four stars for the beer, unlimited stars for the bartender and the crowd.  Its a great place to drink great beer.  Placed in the old North End Cafe's spot, it has the same vibe: Like minded folks liking each other.  This is good.

tMOuv9A8TC-rvMQ5KrD3hw.review_text: If you're a fan of beer you definitely need to stop by Church Key. It's a small but cozy spot. They have about 15 beers on tap and an extensive bottle listing - with that you're sure to find a beer that suits your taste! The bartender who was working while we were there was really helpful and knowledgeable about every single beer on tap and in bottles.  My boyfriend and I stopped by early on Saturday night (around 8pm) and were able to snag a seat at the bar. It got a lot busier later in the night. The sign for the bar is a bit ambiguous so just look out for the lit up key over the door!

dkkMQorZE0EF-F5wOiqA7w.review_text: Always fun to try somewhere new...   As soon as I arrived it cleared out, so I am not sure what that was about, I did shower. The beer was really good, flavorful and strong. It was a one and done. A nice addition to the North Beach scene, and apparently you can even grab a pie there, and the owner makes really good ones.   Had some friendly conversation with the locals.  Was a bit hard to find as there is not a specific sign that says Church Key, you just have to look at the sign with a key.

ZjBGkPbzgRfvoekv6Syw9Q.review_text: My girlfriend and I went there it a place that you relax and not worry about what people our thinking, the drinks were good and the bartender is nice we were able to have a conversation without people interrupting us. So next time well bring some friends

wZG2xlICfUkJiY1NdPJH2A.review_text: love the laid back ambiance.  Must get the Coconut Porter from Maui Brewing Co. So delicious! Definitely low key, cozy, muted, and wait... clean bathrooms! Service was excellent and beer selection perfect. Nice tunes though they should kept the live dj and dance floor upstairs. So non-North beachy... it's great! Wish I could keep this a secret

kMYBGRBSMLkkoUYeNUhcNQ.review_text: Like this place a lot!! Unassuming and chilled, fantastic beer selection, nice bartenders, i dig it!!

LU7ikPXZ5R8tv4oNQZQkKw.review_text: Good selection of beers.  They need to play music that won't put you to sleep.  Drinking a beer in the dark with chill music makes me want to go to sleeeeep.  Some of the beers they sell are priced like bottles of wine.  CraZy.

CfV_axQI2rK0eHB9FfG_GQ.review_text: What a great little beer bar! I really like the decor and atmosphere; since we were the first ones in at 5:15 on a Sunday we had a relaxed, friendly visit with the bartender. They have TONS of beers on their list, though don't expect them to have all of them in stock in the small beer fridges. Only gripe was that the prices of the bottles were insane in some cases. A beer you can buy at City Beer Store, Healthy Spirits or Beer Rev for $15 or so would be almost $30. Not sure why the huge mark up. Definitely stop by if La Trappist is closed and you want your Belgium fix without dealing with the bros at Rogue.

F5PeWdJZqT8BAQD7LnY6_Q.review_text: Pretty interesting hole in the wall type place in north beach. I work in the area and must've walked past it during the day a million times and never noticed it was bar till one night I was there late. Good beer selection, decent prices but pretty limited hours. Also the artwork upstairs made it feel a bit exorcism-y.

dfYNTBw--CYlZbFz581kYQ.review_text: Strangely I'm craving beer today (and I thought I was over beer!)... but not just any beer... Church Key beer! Uh oh! Might mean a stop-by is needed tonight...

shfhrdFn8aGgFP8dyXNyxg.review_text: A fantastic place to explore sour beers! Intimate and pleasant decor in a fun location and the bartender was awesome - super helpful, attentive, and fun. Well, she flirted with me. I'm a sucker for that.

dVzvSnYe_pY_8GOE-QDQQQ.review_text: Really dig this place.    Great beer on tap, with all sorts from bottles as well. Low key atmosphere and very knowledgable bartender to boot.

3t2oRnqVpvPDbFhfrKpeXQ.review_text: If you want great beer in a loungey yet unpretensious space, Church Key is it! They have a big yet awesome beer slection with a helpful bartender. The bar is girl friendly especially for those just learning about beer. The only negative is that this space is a bit small and tends to get overpacked.

h0FPJR1jCDpwq0C4t8ArLA.review_text: A quiet, understated bar in the heart of North Beach. The draught beer selection is great, and the bartenders are very knowledgable about what they pour.  One of our favorite ways to drink here is ordering a sample of 5-6 beers, bartender's choice. Tastes are about $2 each, and you try some styles of beers you might not otherwise pick.

hE34xpG35WugHznWf79HfQ.review_text: Clearly I have been drinking, since I have not been spending my time writing reviews. But where, you ask, and what? Oh, you didn't ask.... well I don't give a crap; I am going to tell you anyhow.   I have been drinking beer that tastes like cocoa butter slathered on some hot body on a warm day, and I have been drinking it at Church Key, because they are the only place I have been in SF that serves a beer with this distinct flavor.   They have a lot of other delicious unique beers as well, in a cool, cozy, faux brick, hip, framed bugs on the wall and fancy lighting fixtures to compliment the tattoos of the bartender type of way (you know the type, right?). They also have a dark upstairs loft where you can probably get away with licking any beer off any body, but that is up to you.

YlJNqoHqIssCHP25h2sUFA.review_text: Feeling the need to update my Church Key review.  It definitely wasn't fair to base it on one night, especially on a busy night.  I've been here a few times since then and I find that it's best when it's not crowded (ie don't go on a Friday or Saturday night) and you can sit and relax with a good beer and good friends.  Their selection of beer is pretty great, with several on tap and even more in bottles (or cans as we found tonight, thank you Oskar Blues Old Chub).  The crowd on quiet nights is usually pretty mellow which is what I love about this place.  They play music on an old record player which has charm and isn't too loud so you can still have conversations.  That being said I'll still stand by some of my earlier review.  I do remember it getting rather hot upstairs when it's crowded so just be prepared for that if you go on a night that it is.

H_DAhIymP_8kpu1kw07Xtw.review_text: solid little beer bar in the heart of north beach! there's one bartender manning all the guests. we grabbed two seats at the bar on a recent friday night, it was pretty quiet because it was early, but the bar was fullll. all drafts are $7, and there's a good rotating selection. i was stuckkkk on the christmas bomb! it was so nomsies, lots of layers of flavors - at about 9% ABV, it is served in an 8 ounce pour.   we went a few rounds, checked out the bottles llst, which is in the form of a small binder, but i'd stick with the drafts. cheaper and fresher and in season! the best part is you can buy a beer for someone  as indicated on the chalkboard behind the bar - for example, james from london bought a drink for the next english guy. pretty nice!

qyPIxexV1Bi0W8Nm11F2CQ.review_text: Stay away...there are better bars in the area! Overpriced,dirty, horrible drinks and rude staff -those are my only impressions of this place!

eQJtcM6rK0-x2F2UlZaNJg.review_text: Nice little beer bar!  Great selection, nice staff and a clean place.  Since it's small I'll assume I should avoid it during the usual high traffic times, but on a Sunday afternoon it fit the bill.  I watched Kia B. have a beer revelation here.  It was quite a sight to behold.

tZ7guKlHjEg0ZhBHt6fCyg.review_text: Killer beer selection, great vibe, nice music.

FuQEA599CgkRu2QZ70TkgA.review_text: Alright, as far as chill spots around North Beach, this and La Trappe are my GO-TOs for beer.  Church Key has a great selection as well as solid prices that both Nifty Thrifties and Baller Shot Callers can appreciate. The place has a lot of character, and its a dive bar you can be proud to frequent. For newbies, it can be hard to find--especially for those of you who are bad at wheres waldo. Look for the closet sized store front on convoluted Grant St with a key over the door, thats it.  This one lacks seating though, and gets really crowded Fri-Sat. Come early to chill out, or maybe at night to stand around and listen to someone spin.

YC4xH6hxgAQks-ngsr_Whg.review_text: A tiny little gem in the heart of North Beach that appears to cater exclusively towards locals.  Grab a seat at the bar, be overwhelmed by the huge selection of beers, poll the bartenders and your fellow barflies on what you should order and then presto!  A lovely beer and conversation.  I walked out wanting to check out all of the great sounding places that were recommended to me.  As for the beer selection, you won't find Bud, Guinness, Sierra or any of the other regular suspects.  Think Toranado, but cleaner.

I-FmdvI28N7OIIt4JZOgIg.review_text: Simple bar place that offers more room upstairs!  They only serve beer and the ambiance to this place is very low key!    I dropped in on this place one evening and in seconds, there were many cop cars that surrounded this place!  Some sort of drug dealer was caught right in front of this dive bar!  Nonetheless, enjoyable place for drinks and chit chatter!

h_ewbDmZ3M3Z2QfyAqm24w.review_text: Was looking for a nice low-key hang out spot in North Beach on a Wednesday night and was shamelessly drawn by the 2 for 1 sausage special. Loved the vibe, small local feel, chill music that was not too loud to have a good convo with friends. The 10+ page beer menu is amazing and meticulously (yet not annoyingly) detailed.. Ordered: Duchess de Bourgogne- sour, fruity, red-ale style beer, yumm!! La Caracole Saxol- smooth blonde ale, sweet malt with a touch of spice, also recommended Wild Game sausages- I tried the boar and rabbit, came served with a slice of sourdough bread and sauerkraut, good stuff when paired with your beers.. Unfortunately wasn't able to spend enough time here given its early closing on that night so will hopefully be back, maybe on a weekend next time, to try out some more beers from their extensive menu!

DYhdsxqPPUhpZfwILtlo1g.review_text: Beer me!   I do like this place. They have a great beer selection, scratch that, they have an amazing beer selection!  The bartender is helpful at getting  you a beer that you would like and appreciate.  I love how they list percentages of alcohol so you can maximize your drink to drunk ratio.  My only problem is SOMETIMES this place can be dead.  The last thing I want to do is sit in a bar all by myslelf drinking exotic beers.  That has alcoholic written all over it.

aZSVgQ9neOltdxViIwSzTg.review_text: What is up with the bartender Ben's snarky and cocky attitude.  It doesn't get the ladies and it also doesn't get return customers.  However, as a local in North Beach, I can't help but choose this bar as my go to place, with an ever changing beer list that intrigues and tantalizes, as well as some pretty awesome records blaring overhead.

ztd0ck9f5dCQK322QuiZHg.review_text: Service was very poor. Place was dead. Small. Shabby. Good beer selection is their saving grace. They had a rare German bier that was from my date's little village in Bavaria. So that should have scored me points but I can't be sure because it's just all so ambiguous. Anyways probably wouldn't return.

2--3--v8yHU3a3FljCcBRg.review_text: AWESOME bar in North Beach with a GREAT beer selection.  Their beer list boasts Allagash Curieux, Dogfish's 90-minute IPA, Stone's Double Bastard, and Young's Oatmeal Stout.  Yes this place has something for everyone.. as long as you're a beer enthusiast.  Otherwise, you can get the *American Mystery Beer* which is just a bottle of America's finest, meaning it could be Mickey's, Natty light, or if you're lucky, the champagne of beers.    Other than the beer selection this place is just chill, nice calm atmosphere, cool bartenders, and just a great place to sip on an awesome beer and hang out.  Go to golden boy after to sober up.

0M6iVk5VtlS9wk45FfPvZw.review_text: I stopped in for a beer on my way back from the butcher.   -a very loungy feel...complete with funk, jazz, dub music and Harry Conrick Jr. with a forehead scar tending a bar of expensive, but good, beer.   When I went (6ish), I was literally the only person there, so I can't comment on the crowd. Small place on a narrow strip of grant st, which looks great. -But you might have to wade through dawdling tourists. The decor is something of the, cigar room+12yro's tree house+mod touches. I liked it.   Beer and wine only. They have a large and diverse beer selection. Personally, I was hoping it'd be more extensive...a collection! The list has 50-75 beers. I had a good Saison (Belgian farmhouse style ale) that was on tap for $6.   On the other side of Columbus in North Beach is kinda far...and remember, there is absolutely no parking.   I'll be back to try a new beer soon.

0pElQxebrLfIezkediVQVQ.review_text: I gotta say that Jason has succeeded again. His other bar, the Broken Record, became one of SF's  best scotch bars within a year or two. Now he's moving on to beer and from the looks of it on my visits, he's succeeding again.   While I usually prefer bars with some liquor, it never actually crosses my mind when I'm at the Church Key. There is such a ridiculous range of tastes that you get a bit obsessed with finding your next brew. Seriously, some of the beers here really change the way you think about how a beer should taste.   The best thing though, and this holds for the Broken Record when it comes to buying scotch, is that Jason is super helpful when it comes to making your choice. He doesn't make you feel like an idiot for asking questions and seems to make it his mission to find you a beer you'll like. Just give him a vague idea of stuff you like and he'll hook you up. I definitely recommend this place if you're in North Beach and want to hang out in a chill place free of the normal douchiness of North Beach.

jy_RGAeAvNeCv5BxZsUWFA.review_text: I'm not a very well followed yelper. I've deduced from my FUC's that there are between 10 and 20 people reading my stuff on yelp. I believe that among the few people reading my reviews there are some really influential yelpers and maybe that makes me influential in a way.   I've noticed that once I give certain places a good review within two months the place is packed. Am I the fountain head or part of the water, part of the process? Am I just at the front of the wave?  I loved The Church key, unequivocally!   There is only a key for a sign and it's the easiest place in the world to miss. I was looking right at it and still didn't see it until I checked a piece of paper that I wrote the address on.   They have an excellent selection of beers without the pretense of La Trappe or Monks kettle. I had the quadrupple at 11% ABV and enjoyed the hell out of it. This is my new favorite place in North Beach.

XN7gmypk2antDlllPKFgxQ.review_text: Vic + Good Beer = Happy Vic  I'm by no means a beer snob, if such a thing exists... but good beer always brings a smile to my face.  We came one a random weeknight (either Wed/Thur). Not many people here... which wasn't bad thing at all. I forget which beers I had... but they were both delicious.  Definitely a place I want to go back.

IC8jJYeX3fzzogfP1VwbJQ.review_text: Great (but only if you like drinking beer to feel a little bit like homework).

DzjvkZwIEeIVL0lIRSKEtw.review_text: I was in North Beach, which is where I am most rarely, and a friend took me here. Said they've got really good beers, which is what I'm into if I'm not at a bar solely to see if I can talk to pretty girls without being awkward. I must say that I was impressed, and as my football coach in high school used to say, "It's the little things that count, Nick. It's the little things. You gotta wake up early in the morning, get a banana in your belly, you know, get your potassium, and do a lap or two, get a good stretch on. . . ." shit, I'm rambling again, aren't I? So yeah, the little things make this place fucking charming. The wallpaper is demons. They've got a beer that tastes like smoked meat. The people are classy and approachable. The bathroom flush doesn't scare me like the one at every Starbucks in the world. And I believe there are at least 5 beers on the menu with an alcohol percentage over 10%, and they taste GOOD! I will go there again. Oh yes, I will.

AsjL5K34C7QgXiT3rCN_9w.review_text: Excellent addition to North Beach!  Solid Beers and great low key atmosphere.  Tucked away on Grant Street, this place is my favorite low key spot to have a great craft beer and relax in North Beach.   Solid music - via Ipod to set for a great relaxing vibe.    Will be back for sure.

DpkpCFdMKYSJAYAPtkvq_g.review_text: My brief was to find a nice, quiet bar that wasn't too expensive. So I go to Yelp and look for lounges $-$$. Ooooh, Church Key has only been open for a month and has 5 stars. I felt very trendy in suggesting such a new hotspot :)  I like the way the bar was on the quietest block of North Beach and denoted by a simple church key sign. The barman was friendly and knowledgeable about the eclectic beer selection. It had a cool vibe, definitely a place to have a quiet conversation with friends or perhaps go on a date.  I would say that the selection is not necessarily any better than La Trappe and Monk's Kettle, and certainly Toronado has more beers on tap.   In addition, they had the door open all night and it was FREEZING!  Overall though, a good place to drink some interesting beer and have a quiet night. If you want somewhere a bit more lively, I would go to Monk's Kettle or Toronado.

GCuDiPUKYxhgFHP5LqJa2Q.review_text: What an improvement from the old Magnet!  First of all, it's no longer empty all the time.  Secondly, it's no longer too dark.  It's perfectly lit for a bar/lounge.  Thirdly, there's no incense burning.  Also, no funky white cloths on tables!  Let's just fast forward...it's so much better and interesting, seriously!  The vibe is cool, friendly and relaxing.  We were greeted by the bartender (one of the owners name Jason?) as soon as we walked up to the bar.  He even moved someone's top away from the counter to get us seats.  He then asked if we've been in and went on to tell us about the place, gave us the menu.  I asked about the food and he apologized because they were all out for the night - someone just ordered the last duck confit meat pie. DAMN!    He told us to ask if we had any questions or if we wanted to have a taste on any of the drafts.  I tried the 90 minute IPA and liked it.  Hubby tried Oaksted (sp?) Bastard and liked his.  A regular, Don (maybe another part owner?) was very friendly.  He is a distributor and has a couple of the wines served there.  He even offered us a taste of his bottle of Black Orchard, a champagne like beer - maybe a nice start for any ladies who are not into beer.  It was really a nice evening enjoying good beer and chatting away with other patrons.  To end the evening, we both tried a lighter beer in bottle.  Hubby had something from Germany and I forgot what I had but I picked it because the description says very carbonated.    If you enjoy beer, you need to check out this place.  It has 8 drafts and about 50 varieties in bottles or cans from 12 oz. to 24 oz from $5-$20+ all around the world.  Yes, plenty with high alcohol content so drink accordingly.  They do have a one page wine list including Sofia sparkling wine.  Both the menus, yes even the beer menu, has a simple description of the flavor.    We also met another patron who happens to be a neighbor across the street!  This maybe the best beer pub in North Beach.

aNKbZV7sTLqeZau7hf7fJQ.review_text: Great selection of obscure, high-end beers, staffed by friendly and knowledgeable bartenders. This place leaves the ridiculously over-rated Toronado in the dust.

1T3wowEMmP3U1K3RRdI61g.review_text: Really love this place. Of course for some reason by the time I get there I am usually already two sheets to the wind and upon leaving am officially three sheets.   New goal for this weekend, start at Church Key, end the night elsewhere. haha.

T1upaPMzuW7pNj74fO1rjA.review_text: I found Church Key through Thrillist.com (*waves* Thanks Thrillist!) earlier this year and was pleasantly surprised. The interior is a little sparse, but the beer selection is solid. The bartender is very helpful in helping you choose, which is a plus since I could go nuts trying to pick. The only downside is that some of the beers are really expensive (25 dollars for a beer? No thanks!) and the music could use an upgrade.

gfyW0vuJls8ARoHmogfcmw.review_text: Super low key place where you can just chill with your friends without going deaf or being crowded.   They have music (kind of a random variety of stuff plays throughout the night) comfortable seating, and it's spacious.    The bar has a huge selection of beers on tap, including pomegranate beer, a fruit cider that wasn't overly sweet, a smoky beer that was reminiscent of beef jerky....  And they also have melt-in-your-mouth fried pork rinds for purchase  No cover, and it's totally unpretentious.  Only downside - they close at 12am :(

ooU_nkSOHtcMdlRdvPHDTg.review_text: The Church Key is hands down my favorite bar. You can barely notice it from the street (luckily it's not on Columbus) so only people who know what awaits them inside come in. This is definitely one of those places you don't want tons of people to know about but it's so fucking awesome it's hard not to want to tell everyone!! Absolutely phenomenal selections of beer. Well done!!

4mzGeIRXTrzC85xjYqYGSw.review_text: This place is run by jerks.  Always "closed"!

DZnK4o2UmAidIf_1_eSEqw.review_text: My boyfriend and I stumbled across this bar randomly on NYE 2013 and are so happy we did!  The place is small and unassuming but the beer list sure is not.  We came to SF at the last minute for a trip and did not have any plans in place, which is how we ended up in this awesome little place.  The bartender was super informative and (somewhat surprisingly) a great mc and dj.  I would absolutely return to this bar the next time I am in SF.

Ln0Q0eO_GQ8A8-zu8d_7Pw.review_text: Beware if you have a large group. This place is super tiny, composed of only a small bottom floor and an upstairs loft area. I was trampled on many times and heard others grunting under their breath that the place was too small. I do like the fact that they have 50 beers to choose from and their wine list is not bad, with reasonable prices for a decent glass of wine. The only problem I had was that I ordered a glass of white wine, which smelled really, really bad. I do give them four stars however, because upon me complaining the bartender agreed that the glass of wine smelled in his words "like a wet dog" and proceeded to open a new bottle for me and pour me another glass without hesitation. That is good service.

qdssYyyQfBJPjIUMEGTykQ.review_text: great ambiance. great beers. great location.  this place is un poco pricey though.  for distinguished taste buds only, otherwise you blow a hole through you're wallet not drinking bud light.

D7muLs_6RcKH97S6fu5zmg.review_text: Update to my previous review: last night, as he helped a fellow patron navigate the beer menu, the bartender referred to the Church Key as a "professionals' only bar."  It was awesome.

WnK7DqYVUrYb7xZFx0k69Q.review_text: I was here on an early friday evening.  It wasn't crowded at all and had a cool atmosphere that was good for just chillen and drinking a really good beer.

eZB9uAnb3CYI4AYYzl5F-w.review_text: Went to Church Key on a Friday night and I had a good experience. It was Super busy and packed so standing may be the only option for you. The selection is better than most bars and they carry about 8 different taps and the rest bottles. The bartender was a bartender, no complaints. A friend of mine even got the end of a keg and wasn't charged for it. I've been to bars that just throw it away. The only thing I wish it had was more space. One of the more interesting things to see was a sign that said "Pliny free since 2008". I like Pliny and Russian River, but I respect their open opinion. I'm more of a empty bar kind of guy instead of a crowded one so ill be back on a weekday.

82dCHyU-ANOgdhxUgZsUeg.review_text: It's a small bar that serves some nice microbrews you won't find at every bar.  Aside from that, when I came, there was a stand-up comedy group going on upstairs so I couldn't not go there and listen in. This is the second time in my life I was at a bar/cafe and a random stand-up comedy group was meeting up to provide a space to practice their material. I had a good Belgian beer in chalet, had a few laughs, then left to my next North Beach bar.  I would rank this spot high on anyone's North Beach bar hopping list. Be sure to include 15 Romolo as well.

onMQq3O_OWqv6JqajDOu3g.review_text: at the corner of an alley in north beach. good music, good beer. really good beer. but you kinda have to know your beer bc they will have some pretty rare stuff. otherwise, you're gonna be paying top dollar for something you might not totally like.

oeSP4tyY8VKMW-ndSMVv1g.review_text: This place was actually pretty cool.  I had passed by it many times without even noticing it.  The drinks were reasonably priced and there was a large selection of beer/wine to choose from.  Only downside was the lack of seating when we went on a thursday night so probably don't suggest going with a group.  I only noticed a couple of tables that could seat more than 2.  If you like beer and want to try something new, Church key has got a large selection to choose from beers all around the world.

dEl_kFfpApgY-zXjAA9Kvg.review_text: Pretty cool little spot in North Beach.  I'm an out of town'er, and we happened upon this place after SF Beer Fest. Decent tap selection and slightly better bottle list. I enjoyed having Cuvee des Jacobins Rogue, as it's one of my go to sours. Pricing is not too bad either.   My friend ordered Firestone 14th anniversary, but the bartender couldn't find it. I would've loved to try that!  -1 star for closing at 12AM.

gC9syNZtvy4iYv4zftxzJw.review_text: I went to Church Key on a Sunday, because I was visiting for Labor Day weekend. My friends who live on Lombard Street walked me there - I guess it's their local hangout spot. And rightly so! Church Key's atmosphere is something I can't quite put into words yet (it felt oddly nostalgic), but I will say this: Patronizing that bar is one of about three reasons why I've decided to move to San Francisco. As I was sitting on the stool, I looked over at my friends and said, "Oh my god. I think I'm going to move here." The lady bartender I encountered was rough around the edges (maybe a bit too rough), but I have to give it to her on the music selection. She was rocking Refused and some other really great bands, so I'll take a few death stares for that. Also, I think she was displeased with mine and my friend's request to drink coffee. She obliged us, despite her obvious annoyance at the request. C'est la vie, especially because our other friends were drinking. Honestly though . . . one of THE best times I've had at a bar without drinking booze. That's gotta be a world record or something! I'll definitely be there often when I move up.

lxOcZ1VZ58nSCFgcunecjw.review_text: Such a small place but Church Key holds a lot of character.  The selection of beer here is like nothing I've seen in San Francisco.  There literally are pages of beers that they have available from all over the world.  Our bartender wasn't too responsive or on his game but it might have been the owner who had a lot of knowledge about beers and gave some good advice.  The beers are a little expensive but you expect that in coming to a place like this.

bg0UwYapIKm6-bFkuaGEMg.review_text: Fantastic beers and great music intermittently on vinyl.  What could be better?

u6ms8jCUMd3qhlB6hufV-w.review_text: This place is one of the best additions to North Beach in a while.   I can't remember the last time I was really impressed by a new beer. I felt that way about every one I had at Church Key. They've got a ton of beers from Belgium to Canada with descriptions ones you would expect on a wine list. I chose an awesome Canadian beer with hints of hibiscus and pear. It was surprisingly tart, and I was really charmed by the Victorian-goth label. Dorky, I know. I also had a great thick stout that could have doubled for dinner.   The owner (I think his name is Jason?) will spend a long time chatting with you about the beers he stocks and the work he has put in the bar renovations. It takes about 15 seconds to realize that he has poured his heart and soul in this place. He also knows his beers like nobody's business and will admit  he likes the hibiscus and pear beer. Nothin wrong with that.

8KnhKUEcOmLlpsoBGYUdzA.review_text: This place is bar none my favorite in town.  My husband and I have started brewing our own beer, and with that, have expanded our tastes beyond even the Belgian variety, which I must say is a big deal for me, as I have spent the majority of my life sucking down bourbon.  (I am from KY)  We came here for the first time about a month ago and were able to sit at the bar and chat with the main bartendress, Kat, who is super nice and sweet.  The second time we actually met the bartender and his lady, and both are not only non-pretentious, but also extremely educated about their selections.  I might add that the wallpaper in this place is the tits.  We hit Church Key up this past Saturday for some post-SF Beer Week fun and were a tad shithoused by the end of Round 1.  My husband was so affected by the camaraderie on display here, that well into the evening, he decided to announce his run for Mayor of San Francisco.  The bartender, Ben, was quite nice to my husband, under the circumstances, which also gives Church Key a huge thumbs-up, in my book.  Some of the selections I count among my favorites include Dogfish Head's Midas Touch and the Allagash.  The taps are switched out periodically, so you can sample a variety of the bests every few weeks or so.    One thing I would LOVE for them to add is Russian River Ales, such as Temptation and Sanctification.  These folks got an A- in Beer Advocate.

m8nQ9i-Peo5zfZqfnc7LuA.review_text: Came here with my husband during our California honeymoon beer trip. Cool little spot. Very chill vibe. The beer selection was outstanding. Kind of small but they do have an upstairs. After walking up and down hills all day in SF it was nice to be able to just hang up there and have a beer.

XLxgaY6X64BRVF25aqDmXg.review_text: Oh how I love this place, at least in the very early evening. It has fueled recent cravings for beer, when in normal times I would just drink wine or a cocktail. I wish it opened around 3 in the afternoon, rather than at 5, for I, oddly enough, concentrate (on work, study, or reading) so well there. At Church Key, mysteriously to this neophyte, the beer remains delicious with microbubbles even after an entire hour (I limit myself to one, so try to make it last). When the bartender plays great music, not too harsh, I'm happy, and feel like I'm in Berlin or NY, but for that I had to wait until 5 to visit.

0t-O5--DOfS55A620fO_GA.review_text: Look for the picture of an old church key-- there is no name, sign, or verbiage calling out this location!    I like taking my beer snob friends here because of the very impressive menu.  So far all of them have been nothing short of VERY impressed.    The bartender is friendly and approachable.  She is always very happy to please and always willing to give patrons a small sample before they commit to an entire glass of beer.    The crowd here is very interesting-- it's an eclectic mix of artists, townies, hipsters, ....pretty much anyone!  The music played is also a crazy mix.    My most recent visit on a Friday night featured a young photographer/artist.  Her beautiful fantasy photos hung on the wall and were very reasonably priced!  Many bar patrons purchased her work. She spoke to the entire bar just before last call and added a really cool personal touch to the experience.    Church Key closes early (midnight on weekends I believe), so make this an earlier stop rather than later.

txvgzVJIv7kyHNnyZWUFDA.review_text: Lots of Belgium beers and a good vibe on the weekends. I wish more of the beers were on tap instead of bottled. I went on a Saturday night and the place felt a bit cramped and the service was whatevers.

AqBNpXElwesY8zwGXQ2xbA.review_text: This place is a snooze fest. Its generally empty and the beer they serve are micro brews, most I haven't heard of (which is both a good and bad thing). I've been to better!

bLJIo69bG7osEyXxCPSewA.review_text: no cocktails @ this place people....jus wine & beer beer beer....wouldnt have discovered this hidden gem if it werent for parking in front lol....only sign this place has is a key light above the entrance....they were playin MJ records on the old school record player....selection of belgium beer  off tap was good~had the stout stuff....make a stop over here when in the beach

H0DVR43Q_a-0qKJChBxQAQ.review_text: This placed opened just a few months before I moved away from San Francisco, and I loved it. The atmosphere is kind of quiet, dark and moody, but gets louder as the night goes on and more people come in. They have an impressive selection of craft-beers at a very reasonable price, and a very knowledgeable bar staff that can make great suggestions should you want to try something new. It was Church Key that turned me on to my current favorite - Allagash Curieux.  I've taken a group of people from work to hang out in the loft upstairs, had a date at the bar, met girlfriends for drinks, and I've even been by myself for a quick relaxing beer at this place, and everyone has loved it just as much as me.

PEizYQ4dkrdmXjfQpxGj7A.review_text: I live on Telegraph Hill, so having the fantastic beers, nice friendly crowd & warm ambiance at Church Key just around the corner has made this neighborhood WAY cooler.   Good luck Jason and Team in getting the LCB to extend your license past 12, I know it's really disappointing to have to ease a happy, post-multiple-8% beers crowd out the door before the witching hour.  Besides the staff, who are always great, I love: 1) the crowd - it's totally diverse & super-friendly and I meet new interesting people every night I'm there. It's not too noisy, too small to get really crowded (I'm slightly claustrophobic). I especially love meeting the traveling beer nuts from all over who have heard through the grapevine that this is THE place to hit when in SF.  I've never seen one disappointed.  2) the beer! This is really a great place to push your tastes in beer well past your comfort level and discover flavors you didn't know you loved. If you know a brand of beer that you do like, don't go for it again, ask for something similar but with a different taste.  You may not love everything, but you'll definitely find some completely new types that you will. I've tasted my way into some weird corners of the beer world here, and grown to really love the diversity of the Lambic/Sours/Brett family.  3) the meat pies & the wild game sausage (gator, pheasant, venison, and rabbit ATM, sometimes boar).  If you get a chance to catch them when they're doing the food pairing nights, that's a don't-miss.  last time it was 3 courses - cheeses, salumis, and chocolates, and it was *fantastic*.   This place is good for groups, but either a) early, so you can claim the upstairs lounge or b) small - less than 5 people.  Churchkey is great especially with small landing parties of 3 or so.

OVVPi514igEwIXKRI8aCrA.review_text: 3 words: apple beer YUM! :)  I'm not a beer lover but this place could possibly turn me into one. It's a small space but didn't get too crowded for a Saturday night.   They have a large selection of beers so if you're ever feeling adventurous, they have a beer to fit whatever mood you're in. Friendly service. The place attracts a diverse, friendly crowd.  Tip about driving there, DON'T. North Beach is known for having horrendous parking especially on a weekend night.

UzxCvpCQDdoDwPomXHMUgw.review_text: This is a neat place and you can tell it's going to come along nicely.  And what I mean by that is, the atmosphere is still in its infancy.  Which is fun because you can go witness it grow.    I didn't get to stay long but I did get to sample several fine beers (Allagash and Oak Bastard) and check the place out.  I liked the upstairs loft although some found it too hot and stuffy.  Needs more furniture and a fan up there, we all agreed.  It's very dark inside, but that gives the place a nice conspiratorial, speakeasy vibe.  The staff were welcoming and helpful, especially for a bar with many Belgian-style beers.  And the bouncer/hostess lady is hot (in addition to  friendly and helpful)!

k3UDoJwjBIWE9WFSoourvw.review_text: For those of you Belgium beer lover who miss, or maybe don't remember the Belgium pubs crawl on your last trip over the pond, this is the place!   Word of advice, don't go into this place and order a Sierra Nevada, the bartender just might kick you out. Not that he hates Sierra Nevada, it's just this place works hard to maintain an extensive 8-10 page menu of beer from all corners of the world.  Can't decide what you want? Tell the bartender what kind of beers you like and he'll find something that suits you needs. You won't be disappointed in his recommendations.

zGOXKICJ-X6tcoIHaGaITg.review_text: We like to stroll leisurely through Sf on sundays.  A few weekends ago we ended up in Northbeach.  "OOOOh"! I exclaimed, we have to try Church Key.  Laid back and cool, and located in the old magnet space.  After flipping through a 10 page extensive list of brews I chose mine.  And it was in a can!  :/  The CocoNut Porter from Maui Brewing.  Be warned, this is very sweet robust porter.  Described as being 'brewed with six varieties of malted barley,  hops and hand-toasted coconut'.  I am in love. . .   Insider Info: Mr. V also found out that this is carried at Bev-Mo  and grabbed me a four pack. . . . .

DI7mg1oQHeUApMm-9Y-BGw.review_text: As a patron of the city beer store, I was a bit sad when I moved across town. No longer. This place has great selection, friendly people, and you can bring your own records. Can't beat it with a stick.

vRVyOzmEKGOxMFkJI_-XKA.review_text: A friend's recommendation led me here on a Thursday night recently. I had just finished dinner at Sushi on North Beach and we were seeking a place where we could chill out and have a beer. The first thing you notice is Jason the bartender, who is as jovial a host as you can have. Beyond that, it's clear he takes great pride in the variety of the beer menu - a menu which changes virtually every week. And that includes what's on tap.   Try the Aventinus for notes of "caramelized banana" - a tasty and smooth beer that is a bit strong (8%) but worth every penny. I also tried a 14% malt liquor beer that was a bit heavy called samichlaus. I can't wait for food to be included cause I'm DEFINITELY coming back here!

yXlI99c98ruR5ZRDGIUNsA.review_text: Good beer selection, knowledgable bartenders. Pretty chill spot, sometimes has a DJ spinning, yet not too loud to have a conversation.

94f2JzIeAO4RtU5SOjtpGg.review_text: Had a small group of people, maybe 6, meet up at Church Key several months back on a Thursday or Friday night. I get that Church Key might not be the best place for a meet up but we started pretty early.  The folks meeting me there are more typical of pac heights, marina and snob hill crowd. Prime real estate for the ridicule of the edgy bar tender. My friends were spending a lot of money and being respectful. The issue the bar tender seemed to have was that we were crowding the bar toward the bathroom as that's where I had been sitting and my friends joined me. Rather than ask us to move or try to accommodate us with another space he went on with passive aggressive actions and commentary. He barged his way through us with glasses several times, mocked the group in front of his regular patrons and gave some folks who were asking for a recommendation the worst tasting beer on their menu. My friends came to me and said "taste this beer it's what the bar tender suggest...it was like $9 and tasted like it was infected. Way to communicate, barman. Way to be a professional. It's your bar space---Manage it. You certainly didn't refuse the money pouring into your till or tips in your jar. But that's not what it's about right? It's about holding onto this one little place that allows you to continue to believe that you are better than everyone else. This is SF....it's chill and people bar hop on weekends keeping your job in demand and your pocket lined. Don't be a dick.

ZS_SiPpiLocKfYNjRZTeww.review_text: Church Key: your beer selection, atmosphere and patrons are right up my alley but i'm gluten-intolerant and you're a**holes for only having one self-admittedly bad white wine and a cider that is less dry cider and much more alco-pop.  Just give me one decent alternative and I'd be there all the time bringing friends who'd love it.

HF4y2SSKPb80TWjECxCcRA.review_text: Nice bar, please fire the old grumpy woman that plays the bartender!  Seriously, I have never left a negative review on yelp so far. But the lady that is running the bar at some nights is literally doing financial damage to this place.   Had a bunch of customers leaving the place last time cussing what is wrong with her and did not understand what they meant. Now I do. She was rude to a degree where I left my beer untouched, paid and left. While I walked out the door she yelled after me and my girlfriend! Needless to say I did not leave any tip...  Please get rid of her if you want your customers back.

JdYG-9VhkFs6IEyc1ea9fA.review_text: This is my favorite bar in San Francisco.  Now, let's get one thing straight: don't like beer?  Don't go to Church Key.  There are half a dozen not too shabby wines available, but you come here for beer.  That's OK, though, because the beer is amazing.  They have eight or so brews on tap, and at least thirty or forty more bottled from all around the world.  The list changes somewhat every two weeks or so, and covers more styles than I even knew existed.  The menus give great descriptions and inform your choices, the bartenders are knowledgeable, friendly, and funny (with great tattoos!) and the ambiance is great (if you like dark cozy places.)  Hipsterish, but otherwise awesome.  Oh, and try the Mephistopheles Stout.  But don't have two.  :)

uls-cZizgGwlESXA0gb7wg.review_text: Summary:  Great bar with a great selection of quality beers.  Church Key is not easy to find (corner of Grant and Green under a sign with no name, just a white key), but it is worth the effort.  Grant is filled with lively bars which definitely hold their own, though Church Key is the place I go when I want to avoid the crowds and enjoy a craft beer.  The bar offers one of the better beer selections in the city, with thick printed menus available at the bar.  Also, rotating local brews are available on tap, keeping things interesting.  Another point of note is the quality bartenders.  A few regulars rotate and all have an impressive understanding of their offerings and beer in general.  If you are unsure or overwhelmed by the large selection, I am confident you will be in good hands.  This is definitely not the place for a crazy night (closes at midnight), but worth a try after a tough day at work.

FMVQUpa5g5EQsPEzuBMpDg.review_text: Name as many movies starring Woody Harrelson as you can.  If you came up with more than 5 (White Men Can't Jump, Zombieland, Natural Born Killers, People vs. Larry Flynt, Kingpin, and the list goes on...), you would have won the trivia night here. Trivia nights, I love 'em! Just one of the reasons to go to Church Key.   They have a wide selection of beers and a pretty detailed menu that actually describes each of the brews. Beers on tap seem to change pretty often, so there will always be a reason to stop in. I'd say the bartenders lean somewhat towards a 'too cool for school' attitude, but maybe they just prefer having their regulars here. There's quite a bit of seating both downstairs and in their upstairs area. On a weekday, you can definitely chill with a bunch of friends and have plenty of room to sit. I think they set up a DJ upstairs on the weekends, sometimes.   Ok, but it's in North Beach, the land of no parking (or $10 parking lots), so unless you have somehow appeased the parking gods and find parking within 5 blocks of this place, it's not the easiest bar to access. Maybe that's a good thing for the locals. Also be aware that the sign is just a picture of a key so you have to keep your eyes peeled for it, as there's not neon sign announcing its existence to the world.   So if you want to test out your trivia savvy or try out some new microbrews, head on over to Church Key.

CCJ9MEk39jYA2mRNQjkWrA.review_text: When The Big Man is in SF working he finishes his day by stopping in to Church Key for a beer. I have been hearing about the beer wonders for ages & since we all were in town last weekend, I had an opportunity to visit. It was great! It is tiny, dark, & not touristy - everything I like in a San Francisco bar! Beer reigns King here & there are so many choices! If you are a fan of the hop, I would encourage you to try Church Key.  We happened to get here on a very warm Saturday evening - it was in the 80's, unheard of in San Francisco! Things were pretty steamy, and not in THAT kind of way, inside the bar. It was just very warm, kind of crowded, & there is no where to sit other than the bar or a couple of window seats.  If I were in this neighborhood again, this is where I would stop in for some great beer!

RQ2ZkfsL4C-5G449Qrv_Ww.review_text: I've popped into Church Key on a few rare occasions- I don't find myself bar hopping in North Beach very often...or, ever. But there are those rare occasions, and the few times I'd been there the beer selection and vibes were always enticing enough that I wanted to check it out on a more languid weekday with a few close friends.  A friend's sister, visiting from the UK, was staying in a North Beach hostel with her boyfriend and thus I decided on Church Key for post-dinner drinks. We went on a Wednesday. We sat at the bar. The DJ was playing upbeat jazz and soul and it was a gooooood!  I really like the vibe here when its somewhere between moderately mellow and almost loud to the point where you need to start raising your voice. It feels vibrant, yet still relaxing- perfect for mid-week.   As for the selection, well the beers on tap are rotating pints of perfection and they have a great book of bottled as well.   Everything up to this point is good.... but don't expect the bar tender to help you figure that out. This is where Church Key looses some stars. See, I only know a little bit about beer- such as: I like it!!! Other than that, I'm pretty clueless as to what's what save for that golden beers are light and dark ones are heavy, and that IPAs are from India and a stout will make you fat :)   When I asked the bartender about a particular draft I've never had, the answer I got was "well, it's a pale ale, soo... it's kinda light." Well, what do ya know? A beer with "IPA" in the name is a pale ale? Reaaallly??? I wanted to know about the flavor or whatever makes the beer interesting and work $12 a pint! The bartender told me I could have a taste or two of beverages I was curious about.  This only half makes up for the fact that in an establishment known for unique beers, the person serving them appears to know nothing. He also acted aloof and disinterested in taking care of patrons. Not really cool in a small little joint like this  Obviously this guy isn't the only bartender who works here. But still.  I'm also knocking off a points because even though I am one of maybe a handful of people that knows Church Key offers a half off pint to anyone checking in there on Foursquare for the first time, Mr. Charisma behind the bar didn't offer me the deal after bringing it up and explaining how I forgot my phone at home. The one day!!! He didn't even seem slightly amused I knew they had a Foursquare deal. Dude?!? Just indulge my geekiness a little when you see me geeking out! You know? Bartender fail.  I'd throw in a half star if I could, though, for the $1 PBR they serve in a chalice :)

amH97PB5Yk_AZAabksFyWw.review_text: Awesome selection of beers. Although they didn't have the first three I wanted in stock... Cute little tight knit place with neat decor. Showed up around 11:40 on a Saturday night in a group of 5... Ordered beers, sat down, 10 minutes later the bartender told us that they were closing up shop. He was cleaning up the entire place while we sat there and pretty much pounded the rest of our beers. It would have been nice if he had told us they were closing at midnight so that we didn't have to pound our expensive 9% alc/vol brews....lame.

iWB9XmMieth96cD2-6fAaA.review_text: The first time I came here was, I believe, not too long after they'd opened. I'd been walking and drinking all day with santachy, and as the sun began to set, and the rest of the drunken santas left for union square, I wandered in here with a few friends.   We had the whole place to ourselves, and were pleasantly surprised by the beer selection. Also, the bartender (who may have been from boston) was charming and friendly. Possibily he was just happy to have some company.   I went back a couple of months ago, and though it was subsantialy busier, it was still fine place to get a beer. The waitress was helpful, and took time to recomend some beers to my middle aged aunt who's not really much of  a drinker.   In any case, good selection of somewhat obscure brews, good sevice (thus far), though slightly on the pricy side.

fkawweeCwxO7cWq8EgEkFw.review_text: I ran into the Church Key on accident, but glad I did.  This place in North Beach has a great selection of brews on tap and by the bottle.  You'll find some rare and interesting brews, but don't expect to find any weak beers here.... most will be upwards of 7-8%.  The bar is pretty laid back and has a good vibe.  Enjoy.

VOD79PseKkg08eIMvNbNHA.review_text: Long overdue review as I've been coming here since it opened a few years back...definitely in my Top 3 bars whenever I'm craving a beer (along with La Trappe and City Beer Store).  Definitely a great place to stop by on a weekday evening when it's not particularly crowded (and you can get a seat upstairs) and if I recall correct there's a pretty dope DJ on either Wednesdays or Thursdays focusing on lots of old school hits. In general it has a pretty low key vibe and most everyone there are avid beer drinkers which makes for good company and good conversation.  The beer selection here is phenomenal, although it'd be nice if they provided more tasting notes in their menu, otherwise it's like throwing darts when it comes to picking a beer although I'll generally steer towards any of the saisons whether on tap or in the bottle. But if you're completely stuck and undecided, the bartenders are definitely helpful.

50W6VKW498OCuH2itdEbfw.review_text: This is a nice low key pub in North Beach with a solid selection of craft beers. They had about a dozen taps and several pages of beers in bottles.  The downstairs area is pretty small, but upstairs they have a spacious lounge area. It was the perfect escape from the other bars where people were glued to the Giants game.

CBwPegIptHW0vwGsaxcfHQ.review_text: Any bar that plays Meshuggah (and loud enough to hear it from the sidewalk) to get people to leave the place after last call is a winner in my book.    This place really does have great beer.  Not so much the tap selection (which is rather small and ever-changing), but one hell of a bottled selection.  Not the best I've seen, but if you are a total beer geek you will appreciate the selection.  Otherwise you might not know what the hell you're looking at.  One of the beers they had on tap while we were there was this bacon-beer.  No, it didn't work together... man that was some god awful shit!

qe9r7hfzHbNm1amyCPqECQ.review_text: The beer menu is amazing, the bar tenders know their stuff, and the vibe at the bar is just right.    The prices can be a bit high relative to other places, which works for the many beers they carry that you won't find anywhere else, but may give you pause on familiar favorites.

ZV1Zx__ce8FJT_PnroH6ZA.review_text: A very small place with excellent local beers.  I am not a beer drinker, but I was blown away by this place.  Blaecorn Unidragon and something else incredible that I can remember the name of unfortunately... However I can tell you it was velvety and chocolate-y in a very good way.    I remember someone telling me that church key refers to bottle openers!  A wonderful place for conversation.  The bartender was very nice, and she did a great job of describing the different beers on tap. It was a Sunday night!

QTLL0xbcy7AyLUPJogk5kg.review_text: Haha, when you search La Trappe on yelp this is the second result. Yelp, you said it for me!  I just gave this place a 3 star review, then rethought it. Its not a-ok, I am a fan. just not a huge one.   If I didnt live directly across for the aforementioned bar, I might like church key more. I finally came here after being reccomended it every single time I told someone I lived in north beach. Seriously, every time.   And it is a cool little spot. Emphasis on the little. The beer selection IS good but its yet to win me over completely. Maybe I need to come back for trivia and pot pie.

AtO1W65ZqJ2RVo3iMimd4Q.review_text: Went here to try some Belgium beers on  Friday night.  After trying Monk's Kettle we were excited to compare.  We arrived around 9pm, and there was enough room for me and my friend to sit at the bar, but it definitely wasn't dead.  I think the owner was bar tending when we first arrived, and he seemed eager enough to help us find a good beer we would enjoy.  But as the bar got busier and the bartender changed, we were more on our own to pick out our next beers.    They have a mystery beer for $2, which this night was Miller High Life.  I can't believe people come to a bar like this for a MGD, but even the owner admitted he drinks them (especially when he needs to drive later).    As far as prices, I can't complain because my tab was half what it should have been. Some guy kept putting our beers on his tab (and buying us wine) and wasn't even trying to hit on us!    The music was picked by the bartender and played on a turn table.  Started out with Johnny Cash, but then switched to something I didn't recognize (or enjoy as much).  The atmosphere is dark, but friendly.    We gave ourselves a 3 beer limit because from past experience, these beers typically leave us with bad hangovers and lead to poor decisions.  Next time it might have to be a 2 1/2 beer limit.  Can't wait to go back!

b3oJ4cJwG7sgbVAvP-Rs_w.review_text: The selection on tap is enticing but the bartender does not seem concerned with pleasing the customers.  I won't go out of my way to visit again.

Zv-P1-QsgO8INjY7UHMYsg.review_text: Awesome little hole in North Beach's Wall.  Been twice to this little establishment and really enjoyed both visits. It really is not your average NB bar. They have pages and pages of different beers including a delicious dark beer that i swear tasted like a Tootsie Roll!  Now this is not the place to go after a heavy meal. These beers are big in flavor and often size and last I checked there was not a Michelob Ultra on the menu.  I did have to knock off one star because when we sat down stairs at the bar it smelled like bathroom, and that was kind of a mood killer. But the upstairs is odor free.

WF1o6AyXm6-NovD5dFnMOg.review_text: Great new spot in North Beach.  Tucked away on Grant, this little bar is going to make a solid name for itself with its extensive beer list, and more importantly, their great bartenders who know their stuff.  Church Key has a wide and deep selection of foreign beers. I didn't even know that many beers existed!  From Belgium to the UK, this place has stocked up on every beer from every corner of this globe. (Strong ones might I add)  Ben, the bartender last night, was amazing. He was open, willing to talk about the beers and gave solid recommendations.  This is no place to order a Stella, and I think if you were to mention Bud Light you might have a bottle up.... (you get the gist)  One of my favorite beers last night was the 'Kwak' from Belgium. Strong beer ( 9%) I believe, and later I had a beer that was (11%) from...   Yeah, it's hard to remember when the beers here are flooring you.  Check this place out, it's a great find, and is a great introduction to the world of tall pints!

_HVQorAvXWMwJ0cxwDp7Zg.review_text: I went here on a Sat night "beer tour" with some friends and thought this place was great! It's off on a quiet side street in North Beach away from the main drag of Columbus and the owners asking you left and right to come in for dinner. Ugh. So this location was refreshing.   I had the Midas Touch beer. It was a spicy, but not overpowering beer great for a fall night out. And the owner/bartender was excellent. We ended up sitting upstairs in the loft-lounge and he came up a few times to check on us and make sure we liked our choices. Great service!  I only take a star off because they ended up playing music that was a little abrasive (aka metal) for my tastes.

ogKe2zG3WtKU2LF8MlkP4g.review_text: Tactical nuclear penguin! Yes you heard me! Its an imperial stout at 32% abv. And I just had to try it who the hell wouldn't?. Anyways very delicious and a once in a northbeach lifetime tasting some delicious beer from scottland that many would mistake for a hard liquor if they didn't know any better.  Lone behold I will definitely be coming back to church key for the ultimate beer selection and hilarious bartender!

_brL8a7RCoF1QkVFMp9TcQ.review_text: Love it. Super nice bartenders, great beers and atmosphere. One of my favorite bars in the city!

UqOSpuFXffTisC1ahPbaWg.review_text: Love it.....LOVE IT LOVE IT!  This is a great addition to the neighborhood.  I think La Trappe is a bit less expensive, but I really like the location of this place.  Its perfect to stop by and have a couple beers and then move on to the next spot.    It is really small, so be prepared to be in close company.

8t_A2p5RrI3cvATfREs3-A.review_text: If you are a beer aficionado who needs a break from the Toronado, check out newly-opened Church Key for some off-the-beaten-track brews and a knowledgeable and friendly bar staff. Formerly the North End Cafe, then an unfortunately-sterile-feeling, Russian-run bar, the owners are working hard to change the decor back towards the style of this once-beloved local drinking hole.

F1zn5vyTpYV4v02LEfdejA.review_text: Although it's a small bar, it's definitely cozy. You walk in and theres about two small round tables on the left and right before you reach the bar. Environment is very relaxed and super chill. I kind of wish there were more than one bartender. It took about 10-15 minutes of waiting (in a not so packed environment on a Saturday night) to finally get my order in. The bartender is also the DJ so I guess I can't blame him for multitasking so well.   There's a great selection of beers! I've never flipped through so many pages of beer before! They even have a selection of cider and wine for decent prices ($6-8). There's a tiny upstairs lounge area to hang out with friends. Very cozy and very relaxed environment.

ADIMCaJqpUy97l8LMOtHYA.review_text: Visited Church Key for the first time Friday evening, to grab a couple of drinks. Mind you this place seems to specialize in beers, lots and lots of beers, but alas that is lost on me, the non-beer drinker. However, they do have some fantastic red wines. My friend and I got there early enough that we were able to grab the front couch/seat that faces the sidewalk. Great people watching! We sat there and had a couple of glasses of wine and chatted it up. The bartender was really friendly and generous with the pours! This place has a pretty relaxed atmosphere with chill people, nothing too pretentious.

eUmVXP9UnoWtz9NSBwY4jA.review_text: I started going to the space that Church Key occupies back in the late nineties when it was the North End Cafe. Yes, I'm old, get over it.   Anyhow...I've been hearing a lot of buzz about his new beer mecca and popped in with Alyssa G. last night after dinner at Don Pistos. Unknowingly, we walked in during trivia night but were still able to grab a couple of beers (Allagash Witbier for her, Anchor Steam Our Special Ale for me) and had the upstairs loft to ourselves.  The beer was tasty, the company great, and the trivia harder than I would have thought. Congrats to Hipster Holiday Sweater, it sounded like you were running away with things when we ducked out.  Church Key is the type of bar that I could imagine spending hours at with friends on trivia night or bellying up to by myself to work my way through the taps. Either way, I'm a fan and will definitely be back.

dEW7W1vrAwOL1XDtf3dwTA.review_text: Nice place with another extensive beer list and a few on draft. Beer lover rejoice!

itsafKCQAOWrViTzNaTbow.review_text: Overpriced but better than most places around. Plays LP sides on the turn table, now that is cool.

IG9oulUO-tprUZOY4jfG3g.review_text: New favorite bar.  Great staff, relaxed vibe (it's casual but cool, and a good place to go with friends), and of course the BEER.    The location (3 blocks from my place) also happens to be ideal for stumbling home at 2 am after helping my brother drink a bottle of Mephistopheles to end the evening.

JWQe8stuylRF5AG7gX4BxA.review_text: Great beer selection.  Not crowded on a Friday Night.  Nice place to talk and catch up with people.  If you like IPA's, get the Dogfish Head Double IPA, high in alcohol content and pretty tasty.

yq_qqNHc3zR1Zi1Qj0sB3A.review_text: I happened upon this place last weekend and really liked it! It's a small place and they only serve beer and wine. We decided to go for beer that night and I had an amazing macademia and coconut porter. The staff was really helpful and the crowd was lively. I will definitely be going back!

VnNayEuKjMjWWVf1Nij8wQ.review_text: Like everyone else says, a little inconspicuous.  But if you know the corner and look for the key it's not that hard to find.  The beer menu is over flowing with great choices, including a Southern favorite Turbo Dog from Abita Brewing in Louisiana.  The bartender wasn't very friendly.  Maybe he didn't like the fact that the one night in the last year I actually wore a shirt with a collar on it was the night I walked into his bar.  Or maybe I just didn't seem hipster enough.  Although I have to admit that his saving grace was that Pantera was on his playlist that night.  Why the three stars?  Small and decorative but not very cozy.  I expect a warmer atmosphere from a neighborhood bar.  Lastly, they have very few beers on tap.  It's personal preference, but I prefer mine out of a keg.

7yfwAe066qZDjHedoV2h8w.review_text: My current favorite bar.  The bartenders really know about beer and can lead you to an amazing selection from their ten page beer menu.  There is no pretention in this bar, but it's also far from grungy.  Take a seat at the bar and join the conversation or head upstairs to their loft for a more intimate experience, either way, you can't go wrong here.

5ZXT4BQB-C1XjUpKmh7kaQ.review_text: if you're a fan of good beer, and trying new brews, Church Key is for you.  Cozy, dimly lit, with a nice vibe.  Peruse their menu for good descriptions of more beers than you've ever heard of.  Plus helpful commentary from the bartenders regarding your selections.

yfr7xoIX77mmatXrim9EZg.review_text: Definitely a hidden gem in North Beach. Good place to get a low-key drink and they have a great beer selection. Not a ton of seating downstairs, but the upstairs lounge is spacious. Good place for a weeknight beer or to start out the night.

yC8z3ISBoVLdPMoR8PCJkw.review_text: This place is way overrated. Yeah their beer list is good, but nothing compared to Monk's Kettle. I ordered their sparkling wine and was unpleasantly surprised to find it came in a can and tasted pretty awful. They played headbanger rock the whole time, which is cool if you are into that, but I'm not. Maybe its because I've seen pictures of Church Key that made it look ultra fab, but I was pretty disappointed with my experience here. I won't be coming back

kxj7TPtJY2zbEjGV0PYfAA.review_text: We definitely would not have stumbled upon this spot without the help of some locals, but Church Key is totally worth the stop.
