TONS of beers on tap and in bottles.  Their beer menu is huge - it took me about 5 minutes just to pick my first selection.  The bartenders are friendly and knowledgeable when it comes to helping with a pick.    Make sure you sit upstairs.  On a Monday night, there were no other people upstairs so it was a nice, cozy spot to have a drink with friends and sit and talk.    Oh, and did I mention they have a dog?  The owner's dog hangs out in the bar every evening and is super cute and loves pets!  Obviously, this sealed the deal for me.  I love dogs and bars with dogs is just too cute!

oxl--iAcvMX2RWSqGZXcfQ.review_text: I like this place because it's off the main strip of bars and restaurants in North Beach. It's small, hasn't been packed each time I've been in and it's mellow. Unfortunately, I'm not that into the beers on tap, even after doing the $1 samples. They have a pretty extensive list of bottles and I think that's the best way to go. Worth checking out on a Friday if you don't care for crowded bars.

ZgLLB512gp3xDOXEzV0GDQ.review_text: The best part about this place is hands down the beer.  The owner selects it all and is very knowledgeable about his choices which makes it fun.  Honestly though, that's all that I really like about it.  I can never tell when I am there if it's supposed to be upscale-esque or a casual non-divey bar.  There is nowhere to sit and unless you want to go upstairs where it is a. a sauna and b. too effing loud.  Downstairs is super limited on space but not quote small enough to feel ok about blocking the entrance/main area/what have you.  Probably a good place for pre-game, or a Thursday, low key night with delightful brews.

f2kprM12LzRr9KcP_X-87Q.review_text: Where every self proclaimed beer aficionado should come to be humbled and happy. Reddish low-light ambiance, and great upstairs seating area / window booth. It's what you'd expect from one of the nicer North Beach bars, plus a locally unparalleled selection of international brews. If you come for the beer and only the beer, you will not be disappointed.

LdWIjNvjdaAoAfpQhT6F9w.review_text: After several months of anticipation [yes, I kept count!], we finally got a chance to check out Church Key. The space sits a storefront away from the corner of Grant and Green, a skeleton key marking its spot. Its interior is cozy and inviting with seating along the bar downstairs and tables and seating upstairs.   I may not be the beer aficionado, but Church Key seems to provide that venue to try something different and new. It is comfortable enough. There are a bunch of beers on tap, ranging in color, price, and taste. And then, there's the menu with even more hard-to-find brews in bottles. For the non-beer drinkers, a selection of wine/champagne is available. From what I understand, the beers will keep on changing. The good stuff will stay longer, while everything else rotates every few weeks. Not sure what to try? Just ask!  What I'd really love is an email list to inform me of what's new at Church Key!   It IS in North Beach and quite the trek for some of us [a worthwhile one though!]. The best part is that it is just one bus ride to/from home base, Broken Record.

K06taXHoLcwVf2N_5b-wbg.review_text: Small location with seating at the bar or upstairs for a quiet evening with your friends and good beer.  Amazing beer selection and our bartender was very knowledgeable about all things beer related.  A must try for beer lovers.

F9tOE0d09SLkCIZwt8I-0g.review_text: This place is kind of deceiving -- it looks like one of those fancy, snobby wine bars from the outside, and you walk in to order your favorite Pinot Noir (because you're a wine snob, yo), and they ask ya, "Red or white."  Because, well, they have two wines.   Red and white.   Not exactly a Sideways tour.  What they do have is a beer list that's longer than most books, and a fine one too. Everything from that Midwest standby Pabst Blue Ribbon -- in a can -- to some 50 dollar beer that the barkeep remarked that was special occasions. I had a red beer -- don't recall the name -- and it was a fine choice. They really know their beer (read my monologue about 4th Street Vine), so I don't feel stupid about asking for a particular flavor. I tell them what they want, they get it.  What's nice about the place is that it doesn't have that North Beach tourist and drunken college student (read: not the Savoy) vibe; the place is nice enough that people think that they have to act civilized (as said by the barkeep, Benjamin), and the runnin' soundtrack is hip enough to make us older types feel young without the youngins throwing up on our shoes.  I'll be back.

YMZS2HlyK4LzlJU9KZbbNA.review_text: Definitely one of my favorites.  Great beer selection, cool atmosphere, good service, close to my apartment.  And a $2 mystery beer selection for the rough times!  Though last time it was PBR light, which is just wrong.
